2. In pairs, ask and answer questions about what you did during that time. For example: 'What did you do last night?'

3. When you answer, describe a sequence of at least three actions. Use sequence markers like 'first', 'then', and 'after that'.
   • **Example:** 'First, I went home and had dinner. Then, I watched a series on Netflix, and after that, I called my friend.'

4. Be ready to tell the class what your partner did.

tags.teacher_instruction: Write these time expressions on the board: 'last night', 'last weekend', 'this morning', 'two days ago'. Also, write the sequence markers: 'First', 'Then', 'Next', 'After that', 'Finally'. Model a full example before students start the pair work.

title: Sentence Relay: A Past Simple Drill
full_description:
Let's do a fast-paced challenge to practice sentence structure.

1. Your teacher will say a sentence and write a 'substitution' word on the board.

2. The first student must repeat the sentence but substitute one word with the new word.

3. The teacher will then provide a new substitution word for the next student.

• **Example:**
  • Teacher says: 'It was very expensive.' (Writes 'good')
  • Student A: 'It was very good.'
  • Teacher writes: 'life'
  • Student B: 'Life was very good.'

tags.teacher_instruction:
This is a mechanical drill good for reinforcing sentence patterns. Keep the pace quick. Here is one of the substitution chains from the original activity:
Base sentence: 'I drove to the park with him.'
Substitutions: shop -> them -> walked -> her -> we

title: Past Tense Story Chain
full_description:
Let's play a memory game and build a story together!

1. The first person starts the story with a short sentence in the past simple.

2. The next person must repeat the first sentence and add a new part to the story.

3. The next person repeats the whole story so far and adds another part.

4. If you forget the sequence or make a mistake, you are out of the game!

• **Example:**
  • Teacher: 'Yesterday I found 100 kroner.'
  • Student A: 'Yesterday I found 100 kroner and I bought a coffee.'
  • Student B: 'Yesterday I found 100 kroner, I bought a coffee, and I met a friend.'

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a classic warm-up or review game. When the story gets too long to remember, you can simply restart it. For a higher-level challenge, you can require each new addition to include an irregular verb.

title: Message Relay Game
full_description:
Let's test our listening skills with a fun game.

**Part 1: Teacher's Message**
1. The class will sit in a circle or a line.
2. Your teacher will whisper a long sentence to the first student.
3. That student will whisper the same sentence to the next person, and so on, until it reaches the last person.
4. The last student says the sentence out loud. Let's see how much it has changed from the original!

**Part 2: Your Message**
1. On your own, write a long sentence that includes at least two past tense verbs.
2. We will sit in a circle and send your messages around the class in the same way.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity is also known as 'Telephone' or 'Broken Telephone'. For Part 1, use a long, detailed sentence like this: 'We met our friends at the new pizza place on the corner and shared a large pepperoni pizza and a bottle of Coke.' Write both the original and final versions on the board to highlight the funny changes.

title: I Don't Believe You! A Storytelling Challenge
full_description:
Let's play a game that mixes storytelling and bluffing.

1. Work in small groups.

2. One person starts telling the group what they did yesterday.

3. After every one or two sentences, the rest of the group must interrupt and shout, 'I don't believe you!'

4. When you are challenged, you must change the last sentence you said and continue your story with the new 'fact'.

• **Example:**
  • Student A: 'I got up at 7:30 and had a shower...'
  • Group: 'I don't believe you!'
  • Student A: 'Okay... I got up at 10:30 and had a coffee. Then I went out for a walk...'
  • Group: 'I don't believe you!'
  • Student A: 'Okay... I went to the moon. I saw an alien...'

title: My First Time...: Sharing Memories
full_description:
In pairs, share stories about your 'first time' doing some of these things. Tell your partner about the experience.

**Talk about your first:**
• Pet
• Job or summer job
• Friend
• Time living away from home
• Holiday without family
• Memory
• Day at this school
• Car or moped
• Flight on a plane

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a personal sharing activity. Write the prompts on the board. Remind students that they only need to talk about topics they feel comfortable sharing. The goal is fluency and storytelling practice in the past simple.

title: When Was the Last Time You...?
full_description:
Let's practice asking and answering questions about recent experiences.

**Part 1: Last Time Activities**
• In pairs, ask each other questions about the last time you did these things. Give some extra details in your answer.
• For example:
  A: 'When did you last go to the cinema?'
  B: 'The last time I went to the cinema was two weeks ago. I saw the new Dune movie.'

• Activities: eat at a restaurant, take exercise, travel by boat, have a cold, cook a meal, laugh really hard, send an important email, clean your room, tell a lie, stay up all night.

**Part 2: Follow-up Questions**
• In pairs, ask and answer questions beginning with 'What was the last thing you...?'
• After each answer, ask a follow-up question.
• For example:
  A: 'What was the last thing you bought online?'
  B: 'A new pair of headphones.'
  A: 'Why did you buy them?'
  B: 'Because my old ones broke.'

• Verbs: buy, make, break, eat, sell, write, learn, find, read, watch, throw away.

title: First and Last Time: A Verb Game
full_description:
Let's play a competitive game to practice the past simple.

1. Work in two teams.

2. Your teacher will prepare a pile of cards with verbs on them for your team.

3. Take turns picking up a verb card. You must make a correct sentence with that verb, beginning with 'The first time I...' or 'The last time I...'.

4. If your sentence is grammatically correct, your team keeps the card and gets a point.

5. If the other team finds a mistake in your sentence, they can challenge you. If they are right, they steal your card and get the point!

6. The team with the most cards at the end is the winner.

tags.teacher_instruction: Before the game, have students help you brainstorm 20-30 common regular and irregular verbs to write on the slips of paper. This makes the game more student-centered.

title: A Day in the Life: Sequencing a Story
full_description:
Let's work together to create a story about a person's typical day.

**Part 1: Order the Actions**
• In pairs, look at the list of phrases below. First, change the verbs to the past simple. Then, arrange the phrases in a logical order to describe someone's morning.
• Use words like 'and', 'then', and 'after that' to connect the sentences.

   (Actions: wake up, get up, make coffee, have a shower, check phone, get dressed, leave the house, drive to work/school)

**Part 2: Ask and Answer**
• Write one question about each sentence in your story (e.g., 'What time did he wake up?').
• Join with another pair. Ask and answer your questions.

**Part 3: Continue the Story**
• As a group of four, continue the story of the person's day. What happened at work or school? What did they do in the evening? Choose one person to read your finished story to the class.

title: Cause and Effect: Connecting Past Actions
full_description:
Let's practice connecting two events in the past using the word 'when'.

**Part 1: Sentence Building**
1. Your teacher will dictate pairs of short sentences. For example: 'The shark appeared. They panicked.'
2. Rewrite them as one single sentence in the past tense, starting with 'when'. For example: 'When the shark appeared, they panicked.'

**Part 2: Create Your Own**
1. On your own, write two pairs of simple cause-and-effect sentences about your own life.
2. Swap your sentences with a partner. Join the sentences you receive using 'when' and then pass them back.

tags.teacher_instruction:
For Part 1, dictate these sentence pairs for students to join:
1. She read the letter. She threw it in the bin.
2. The bell rang. They ran out of the classroom.
3. The rain stopped. We went outside.
4. I got home. I switched on the TV.

title: Mine or Yours? Possessive Pronoun Drill
full_description:
Let's practice the difference between possessive adjectives (my, your, her) and possessive pronouns (mine, yours, hers).

**Part 1: Class Drill**
• Listen to the sentence your teacher says. Your job is to shout out the same sentence, but using a possessive pronoun.
• For example:
  Teacher: 'It's my book.'
  Class: 'The book is mine!'

**Part 2: Pair Practice**
• In pairs, try to write down all the sentence pairs from the drill from memory.

tags.teacher_instruction:
This is a quick oral drill. Use these prompts for Part 1:
• It's my pen.
• It's her phone.
• That's my bag.
• It's your car.
• This is our project.
• It's their baby.
• This is his house.
• That's their dog.

title: Whose Is It? Object Game
full_description:
Let's play a game to practice asking and answering questions about who owns what.

1. Your teacher will borrow an object from a student and show it to the class.

2. In pairs, practice this conversation:
   • Student A: 'Is this yours?'
   • Student B: 'No, it's not mine.'
   • Student A: 'Whose is it then?'
   • Student B: 'I think it's his/hers/Maria's.'

3. Take turns picking an object and having a similar conversation with your partner.

tags.teacher_instruction: Start by collecting some small, common objects from the students (e.g., a pen, a phone, an eraser, a notebook). Model the exchange on the board first, then gradually erase it as students become more confident.

title: Comparing Ours: What About Yours?
full_description:
Let's practice asking questions using possessive pronouns.

1. Look at the example question: 'My shoes are brown; what about yours?'

2. In pairs, change the noun ('shoes') and the adjective ('brown') to create five new questions.
   • For example: 'My phone is new; what about yours?' or 'My jacket is black; what about yours?'

3. Find a new partner.

4. Take turns asking and answering the five questions you wrote.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a simple but effective pair work activity. Model the example clearly and encourage students to use objects and adjectives relevant to their own lives and classroom environment.

title: Don't Disturb Me! Present Continuous Practice
full_description:
Let's practice using the present continuous to talk about actions happening right now.

1. Your teacher will dictate the beginning of some sentences.

2. Write them down and, in pairs, think of a suitable ending using the present continuous (-ing form).

3. After you finish the list, think of two more sentences that are useful for you in your daily life or at your workplace.

tags.teacher_instruction:
Dictate these sentence starters for students to complete:
• Please turn the music down; I'm...
• Don't listen to him; he's...
• Quick! Pass me the tool; I'm...
• I can't talk right now; I'm...
• Be careful! The coffee is...
• Leave the video on; I'm...
• Look at that car; it's...
• Shhh! Listen. The baby is...

title: What's Everyone Doing? Describing a Scene
full_description:
Let's describe a busy scene using the present continuous.

1. Look at the picture your teacher is drawing on the board (e.g., a house, a school, a workshop).

2. As a class, let's identify the different rooms or areas and decide who is in them.

3. In small groups, imagine it's a busy time of day. Discuss and agree on what each person is doing right now.
   • For example: 'In the workshop, Karim is fixing an engine.' or 'In the classroom, Lise is listening to a podcast.'

4. Now, think about your own family and friends. In your groups, discuss what you think they are doing right now.

tags.teacher_instruction: Draw a simple cross-section of a building on the board. To make it more relevant for vocational students, you could draw their school, a workshop, a salon, or an office building instead of a house. Elicit vocabulary for the different areas before starting the main task.

title: Present Simple vs. Continuous: What Do You Wear?
full_description:
Let's practice the difference between the present simple (for habits and general truths) and the present continuous (for actions happening now).

Your teacher will start a chain of questions. Listen carefully to decide if the question is about habits ('Do you wear...') or what is happening now ('Are you wearing...?').

• **Example 1 (happening now):**
  Teacher: 'Manuel, are you wearing jeans?'
  Manuel: 'No, I'm not. Ilona, are you wearing jeans?'

• **Example 2 (general habit):**
  Teacher: 'Brigit, do you wear a scarf in winter?'
  Brigit: 'Yes, I do. Peter, do you wear a scarf in winter?'

tags.teacher_instruction: The goal here is to highlight the difference between 'wear' (habit) and 'am wearing' (now). Start the question chain yourself, modeling both forms clearly, then let the students continue the chain around the classroom.

title: Guess the Action: A Mime Game
full_description:
Let's play a game of mime to practice the present continuous.

**Part 1: Teacher's Turn**
• Watch your teacher mime an action. Guess what they are doing by saying, 'You are [verb]-ing.' For example: 'You are driving a car.'

**Part 2: Team Challenge**
• Work in two teams.
• One person from your team will come to the front and mime an action.
• Your team has 30 seconds to guess the action correctly to score a point.

tags.teacher_instruction:
Miming can make some students feel self-conscious, so maintain a fun and supportive atmosphere. For your mime in Part 1, and as suggestions for students, use actions like:
• flying a kite
• driving a fast car
• watching a tennis match
• brushing a cat's fur
• drinking coffee
• watching a football match on TV
• listening to a podcast
• taking a selfie

title: Sounds of Your World: Listening and Describing
full_description:
Let's use our ears to practice the present continuous.

**Part 1: What's Happening Outside?**
1. We will all be quiet for two minutes.
2. Open the windows or just listen carefully. Make a note of anything you can hear happening outside the classroom.
3. Use the present continuous to describe the sounds. For example: 'A car is driving by.' or 'Someone is talking loudly on their phone.'

**Part 2: Imagined Location**
• Now, imagine you are in a different, busy location (e.g., at a music festival, in a busy restaurant, at an airport).
• Write a short description of all the things that are happening around you.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a great mindfulness and observation activity. If the area outside your classroom is very quiet, you can play an ambient soundscape video from YouTube (e.g., 'city sounds', 'restaurant ambience') for Part 1.

title: Digital Postcard: Describing Your Holiday
full_description:
In pairs, imagine you are on holiday in a fantastic location.

1. You are sitting in a café, and there's a lot going on around you.

2. Write a short message (like a social media post, an email, or a postcard) to someone back home.

3. In your message, describe what is happening right now using the present continuous. You should include descriptions of:
   • the weather
   • the people you can see
   • the city or town
   • the food and drink you are having
   • your plans for the next day (using present continuous for future arrangements)

tags.teacher_instruction: To modernize the activity, frame it as writing a social media update or a quick email to a friend, rather than a physical postcard. This makes the task more authentic for today's students.

title: What's Happening?: Life, Work, and the World
full_description:
Let's use the present continuous to talk about things happening 'these days' or over a longer period of time.

**Part 1: Your Life These Days**
• In pairs, tell each other what is happening in your life at the moment. Talk about some of the following topics:
  • your studies or work
  • hobbies
  • family
  • routines or habits that are changing

**Part 2: The World These Days**
• In groups, discuss what is happening in the wider world. What are some of the big changes or trends you are seeing?
• Talk about some of the following topics:
  • technology and AI
  • the environment
  • the global economy
  • culture, fashion, or music
• Agree on a list of the three most important trends and share them with the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity helps students use the present continuous for ongoing trends, not just actions happening 'right now'. The topics have been updated for relevance in 2025. Ensure discussions in Part 2 remain respectful.

title: Weekend Planner: Making Arrangements
full_description:
Let's practice using the present continuous to talk about future plans.

1. Copy the weekend planner below. Fill in any three of the six time slots with plans. You can be creative! For example: 'testing a new video game' or 'going to a concert'.

   **Saturday | Sunday**
   Morning |
   Afternoon |
   Evening |

2. Now, walk around the room and try to make plans with other students for your empty time slots.

• **Example Conversation:**
  A: 'Are you doing anything on Saturday afternoon?'
  B: 'Yes, I'm meeting a friend for coffee.'
  A: 'Oh, okay. What about Sunday evening?'
  B: 'No, I'm not doing anything then. I'm free.'
  A: 'Would you like to go to the cinema?'
  B: 'Yes, that sounds great!'

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a classic and effective communicative activity. Draw the planner on the board. You can suggest students use their actual phone calendars for a modern twist, which makes the role-play more authentic.

title: Always Complaining: Describing Annoying Habits
full_description:
We can use 'always' with the present continuous to talk about repeated, often annoying, habits.

**Part 1: Sharing and Advice**
• In pairs, think of a person you know (not someone in this class!) who has an annoying habit. Tell your partner about them. For example: 'My brother is always leaving his wet towels on the floor.'
• Give each other some friendly advice on how to deal with the person.

**Part 2: Guess the Adjective**
• Your teacher will give your pair an adjective that describes a person.
• Write one sentence describing this person's bad habit using 'always + -ing'. For example, for 'lazy': 'He's always leaving his work until the last minute.'
• Read your sentence to the class (without saying the adjective) and see if they can guess the word.

tags.teacher_instruction: This grammar point is nuanced. In Part 1, emphasize that students should not talk about anyone in the class to avoid hurt feelings. For Part 2, distribute these adjectives among the pairs: argumentative, bossy, careless, forgetful, grumpy, lazy, messy, selfish, unreliable.

title: Past Participle Game Show
full_description:
Let's test your knowledge of past participles with two quick games!

**Game 1: Team Quiz**
• Work in two teams.
• Your teacher will read a list of verbs in the infinitive (e.g., 'go').
• The first team to shout out the correct past participle ('gone') gets a point.
• If you are wrong, the other team gets the point.

**Game 2: Noughts and Crosses (Tic-Tac-Toe)**
• Your teacher will draw a Noughts and Crosses grid on the board, with a different verb in each square.
• In your teams, take turns choosing a square.
• To win the square, you must say the past participle of the verb and use it in a correct sentence. For example, for 'break': 'Broken. I have broken my phone screen.'

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity combines two engaging drills from the original source. For Game 1, use a mix of common regular and irregular verbs. For Game 2, draw a 3x3 grid and fill it with common irregular verbs like: see, do, be, eat, write, take, give, make, go.

title: Find Someone Who... (Life Experiences)
full_description:
Let's find out about your classmates' life experiences using the present perfect.

1. You will get a list of activities from your teacher.

2. Your goal is to walk around the room and find a different person who has done each thing on the list.

3. Ask questions starting with 'Have you ever...?' For example: 'Have you ever been to a music festival?'

4. When you find someone who says 'yes', write their name next to the activity.

tags.teacher_instruction:
Provide students with a worksheet or write this list on the board for them to copy. Use this updated list:
Find someone who has ever...
• ridden a horse
• worked a night shift
• sung karaoke in public
• been to a huge music festival
• made bread from scratch
• won a prize or a competition
• slept outside in a tent
• broken a bone
• climbed a mountain
• built their own PC

title: Have You Ever...? A Deeper Conversation
full_description:
Let's practice asking about life experiences and then getting more details.

**Part 1: Pair Conversation**
• In pairs, ask and answer questions about whether you have ever done the things on the list below. Start with 'Have you ever...?'
• If your partner answers 'yes', ask follow-up questions using the past simple to find out more details (When? Where? What happened?).

• **Example:**
  A: 'Have you ever broken a bone?'
  B: 'Yes, I have.'
  A: 'Oh really? What happened?'
  B: 'I broke my arm when I was playing football at school.'

• **Topics:** eat strange food, see a solar eclipse, live by the sea, go on a protest or demonstration, do something brave, sleep in a tent, drive a tractor or large vehicle.

**Part 2: What Do You Think?**
• Tell your partner something you've done that you think is unique in the class. Then, guess something they have never done that you think someone else has.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity is excellent for practicing the switch between present perfect (for life experiences) and past simple (for specific details of that experience). Model the example conversation clearly before students begin.

title: Scene of the 'Crime': A Present Perfect Mystery
full_description:
Let's use the present perfect to be detectives and figure out what has happened based on clues.

**The Situation:**
• Imagine you walk into a room (like a kitchen or a workshop) and it's a complete mess. You are trying to describe what you think has happened.

**The Task:**
1. As a class, let's brainstorm some clues you might see in a messy kitchen. For example: an empty pizza box, flour on the floor, an open window.

2. In pairs, look at the clues and make sentences using the present perfect to say what has happened.
   • For example: 'Someone has eaten the entire pizza.' or 'They have made a huge mess.' or 'The thief has escaped through the window!'

3. Be creative and tell the story of what happened in the room based on the evidence.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity has been re-themed from the original 'romantic dinner' to be more flexible, fun, and less awkward for students. The core grammar point (describing the results of a past action) remains the same. You can draw the 'crime scene' on the board with various clues.

title: Are We Ready? The Preparation Checklist
full_description:
Let's practice using the present perfect to check if we are ready for a big event.

1. In pairs or small groups, choose one of the following scenarios:
   • Preparing for a big holiday
   • Organizing a class party
   • Getting ready for a major project presentation at work/school
   • Preparing for a job interview

2. Make a checklist of ten important things that need to be done before the event. For example, for a holiday: 'book hotel', 'pack bags', 'buy tickets'.

3. Now, imagine it's time to leave or start the event. Role-play checking your list with your partner.
   • **Example:**
     A: 'Have you packed the towels?'
     B: 'Yes, I have. Have you charged your phone?'
     A: 'Oh no, I haven't! Thanks for reminding me.'

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a practical and communicative activity. Write the different scenario options on the board. Encouraging students to choose a scenario relevant to their vocational studies (e.g., preparing a worksite, setting up for a client) will increase engagement.

title: Connecting Past Events with 'When'
full_description:
Let's practice connecting two events in the past using the word 'when'.

**Part 1: Sentence Joining**
1. Your teacher will dictate several pairs of short sentences.
2. Your task is to join each pair into a single sentence using the past simple and starting with 'when'.

• **Example:** Teacher says: 'She heard the baby cry. She went to feed him.' -> You write: 'When she heard the baby cry, she went to feed him.'

**Part 2: Create Your Own**
1. On your own, write two or three pairs of simple 'reaction' sentences about your own life.
2. Swap your sentences with a partner. Join the sentences you receive using 'when'.

tags.teacher_instruction:
This is a structured drill for practicing complex sentences with 'when'. For Part 1, dictate these sentence pairs:
1. The movie ended. Everyone clapped.
2. The alarm rang. I woke up.
3. My phone buzzed. I checked the message.
4. The rain stopped. We went outside.

title: Pronoun Drill: Mine vs. My
full_description:
Let's practice the difference between possessive adjectives (my, your, her) and possessive pronouns (mine, yours, hers).

**Part 1: Class Drill**
• Your teacher will say a sentence like, 'It's my phone.'
• Your job is to quickly say the same thing using a possessive pronoun: 'The phone is mine!'

**Part 2: Memory Challenge**
• In pairs, try to write down all the sentence pairs from the drill from memory.

tags.teacher_instruction:
This is a quick oral drill. Use these prompts for Part 1:
• It's my pen.
• It's her jacket.
• That's my bag.
• It's your car.
• This is our project.
• It's their table.
• This is his laptop.
• That's their dog.

title: Whose Is It Anyway? A Possession Game
full_description:
Let's play a game to practice asking about ownership.

1. Your teacher will borrow some small objects from the class.

2. In pairs, one person will pick an object and ask their partner about it.

3. Use this conversation as a model:
   • Student A: (holding a pen) 'Is this yours?'
   • Student B: 'No, it's not mine.'
   • Student A: 'Whose is it then?'
   • Student B: 'I think it's hers.' (points to another student)

4. Take turns practicing the conversation.

tags.teacher_instruction: Before the activity, collect some small, common objects from the students (e.g., a pen, a phone, an eraser, a notebook) and put them in a bag or box. Model the target conversation on the board. As students get more confident, you can gradually erase the model to challenge their memory.

title: Comparing Things: 'What About Yours?'
full_description:
1. Look at the example question: 'My jacket is black; what about yours?'

2. In pairs, change the noun ('jacket') and the adjective ('black') to create five new questions of your own.

3. Find a new partner.

4. Take turns asking and answering your five questions.

title: Present Continuous Sentence Completion
full_description:
1. Your teacher will dictate the beginning of several sentences. Write them down.

2. In pairs, think of a logical ending for each sentence using the present continuous (-ing form). For example, if the teacher says 'Don't disturb me...', you could finish with '...I'm working on something important.'

3. After completing the list, create two more of your own sentences that you might use in daily life.

tags.teacher_instruction:
Dictate these sentence starters:
• Don't disturb me; I'm...
• Be quiet; the teacher is...
• I can't come to the phone; I'm...
• Look at that dog; it's...
• Leave the video on; I'm...
• Quick, pass the tool; I'm...

title: Describing a Busy Scene: What's Everyone Doing?
full_description:
1. Look at the picture your teacher is drawing on the board (e.g., a school, a workshop, an office building).

2. As a class, let's identify the different areas and decide who might be there.

3. In small groups, imagine it's a busy time of day. Discuss and agree on what each person is doing right now. Use the present continuous.
   • For example: 'In the workshop, Karim is fixing an engine.' or 'In the canteen, Lise is drinking a coffee.'

4. Now, think about your own family and friends. In your groups, discuss what you think they are doing right now.

tags.teacher_instruction: Draw a simple cross-section of a building relevant to your students' vocational field (e.g., a workshop, a salon, an office, a kitchen). This makes the context more meaningful than a generic house. Elicit vocabulary for the different areas before starting the group task.

title: Habits vs. Now: Present Simple vs. Continuous
full_description:
Let's practice the difference between the present simple (for habits) and the present continuous (for now).

Your teacher will start a chain of questions. Listen carefully to the verb form to know how to answer.

• **Example 1 (happening now):** 'Are you wearing a watch?'
• **Example 2 (general habit):** 'Do you wear a watch every day?'

You will answer the question and then ask another student a similar question.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a question-chain drill to highlight the difference between 'wear' (habit) and 'am wearing' (now). Start the chain yourself, modeling both question forms clearly (e.g., 'Maria, are you wearing black shoes today?' -> 'Yes, I am.' Then, 'David, do you usually wear black shoes?' -> 'No, I don't.'). Then have students continue the chain around the room.

title: Action Mime Challenge
full_description:
Let's play a game of mime to practice the present continuous!

**Part 1: Teacher's Mime**
• Watch your teacher mime an action. The first person to correctly guess what they are doing ('You are...') wins a point for their team.

**Part 2: Team Mime**
• Work in two teams.
• Take turns to send one person from your team to the front to mime an action.
• Your team has 30 seconds to guess the action correctly to score a point.

tags.teacher_instruction:
This activity is fun but can make some students feel self-conscious, so maintain a positive atmosphere. For your own mimes and to suggest to students, use this updated list of actions:
• flying a drone
• driving a fast car
• watching a tennis match
• scrolling on TikTok
• listening to a podcast
• taking a selfie
• fixing an engine
• playing a video game

title: Audio Postcard: Describing a Scene
full_description:
Let's use our listening skills to describe a scene with the present continuous.

1. Your teacher will play an audio clip of a busy place (e.g., a city street, a market, an airport).

2. Close your eyes and listen carefully for 1-2 minutes.

3. Make notes on all the different sounds you can hear. What is happening?

4. In pairs, compare your notes and write a short paragraph describing the scene as if you are there. For example: 'A train is arriving at the station. Many people are talking loudly. A baby is crying.'

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a great listening and writing activity. Instead of relying on the sounds outside the classroom, find an ambient soundscape video on YouTube (search for 'city ambience', 'restaurant sounds', 'airport sounds', etc.). This gives you control over the audio input.

title: Writing a Holiday Update
full_description:
1. In pairs, imagine you are on holiday in your dream location. You are sitting in a café, and it's a busy, interesting place.

2. Write a short social media post or an email to a friend back home.

3. In your message, describe what is happening right now using the present continuous.

4. You should also include:
   • A description of the weather.
   • What people are doing around you.
   • What you are eating and drinking.
   • What you are planning to do tomorrow (use present continuous for future arrangements, e.g., 'Tomorrow we are visiting the museum.').

tags.teacher_instruction: Encourage students to be creative with their 'dream location'. Framing the writing task as a social media update or email makes it more authentic for this age group than a physical postcard.

title: Trends and Changes: Your Life and the World
full_description:
Let's use the present continuous to talk about ongoing trends and changes.

**Part 1: What's Happening in Your Life?**
• In pairs, talk about what is happening in your life 'these days'. What are you focusing on? What is changing?
• You can discuss topics like:
  • Your studies or apprenticeship
  • Hobbies and interests
  • Your daily routines

**Part 2: What's Happening in the World?**
• In small groups, discuss some of the big trends happening in the world right now.
• Consider topics like:
  • Technology (e.g., AI, social media)
  • The environment
  • Culture (e.g., music, fashion, movies)
• Agree on the three most important trends and prepare to share your ideas with the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity helps students practice using the present continuous for longer, ongoing situations, not just actions happening at this exact moment. Ensure the discussion in Part 2 remains respectful and focused on general trends.

title: The Weekend Planner: Making Future Plans
full_description:
Let's practice using the present continuous to talk about future plans.

1. Draw a simple weekend planner with slots for Saturday morning, afternoon, evening, and Sunday morning, afternoon, evening.

2. Fill in any THREE of the six slots with plans you have. You can be creative! For example: 'testing a new video game' or 'going to a concert'.

3. Now, walk around the room and try to make plans with other students to fill your THREE empty slots.

• **Example Conversation:**
  A: 'What are you doing on Saturday afternoon?'
  B: 'I'm meeting a friend for coffee.'
  A: 'Okay. Are you doing anything on Sunday evening?'
  B: 'No, I'm not doing anything. I'm free!'
  A: 'Would you like to see a movie?'

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a classic communicative activity. Draw the planner on the board. You can suggest students use their actual phone calendars for a modern twist, which makes the role-play more authentic. The goal is to practice both asking ('What are you doing...?') and answering ('I'm visiting...').

title: Describing Annoying Habits with 'Always'
full_description:
We can use 'always' with the present continuous to complain about repeated, annoying habits.

**Part 1: Sharing & Advice**
• In pairs, think of a person you know (IMPORTANT: not someone in this class!) who has an annoying habit.
• Tell your partner about them using the 'always + -ing' structure. For example: 'My brother is always leaving his dirty dishes in the sink.'
• Give each other some friendly advice.

**Part 2: Guess the Adjective**
• Your teacher will give your pair an adjective.
• Write one sentence describing a person with this quality, using 'always + -ing'.
• Read your sentence to the class (don't say the adjective!) and see if they can guess the word.

tags.teacher_instruction: It is very important to stress that students must not talk about anyone in the class to avoid hurt feelings. This is a practice activity about language, not a chance to complain about classmates. For Part 2, distribute these adjectives among the pairs: argumentative, bossy, careless, forgetful, grumpy, lazy, messy, selfish, unreliable.

title: Present Perfect Game Show
full_description:
Let's test your knowledge of past participles with two fast-paced team games!

**Game 1: Verb Race**
• Work in two teams.
• Your teacher will say a verb (e.g., 'speak').
• The first team to shout out the correct past participle ('spoken') gets a point. If you're wrong, the other team gets the point.

**Game 2: Noughts and Crosses (Tic-Tac-Toe)**
• The teacher will draw a 3x3 grid on the board with a different verb in each square.
• Take turns choosing a square for your team.
• To win the square, you must say the past participle and use it in a correct present perfect sentence. For example, for 'take': 'Taken. I have taken the bus today.'

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity combines two engaging drills. For Game 1, have a list of common irregular verbs ready. For Game 2, draw the grid and fill it with verbs your students find difficult, like: see, do, be, eat, write, give, make, go, break.

title: Class Survey: Have You Ever...?
full_description:
Let's find out about your classmates' life experiences!

1. Your task is to walk around the room and find a different person who has done each thing on the list below.

2. Ask questions using the present perfect: 'Have you ever...?'

3. When someone answers 'yes', write their name next to the activity on your paper.

tags.teacher_instruction:
This is a classic 'Find Someone Who...' mingle activity. Provide the students with this updated list of experiences:
• ride a horse
• work a night shift
• sing karaoke in public
• go scuba diving
• make bread from scratch
• win a prize in a competition
• sleep outside in a tent
• break a bone
• eat something very strange
• climb a mountain
• build your own PC

title: Present Perfect to Past Simple: The Conversation Flow
full_description:
Let's practice how a natural conversation flows from a general experience to specific details.

1. In pairs, ask and answer questions starting with 'Have you ever...?' using the topics below.

2. If your partner says 'Yes, I have,' ask follow-up questions using the past simple (What...? When...? Where...? Why...?) to find out more.

• **Example Conversation:**
  A: 'Have you ever seen a wild moose?'
  B: 'Yes, I have.'
  A: 'Wow! When did you see it?'
  B: 'I saw one last year when I was hiking.'

• **Topics to discuss:**
  • cut your finger badly
  • eat Indian food
  • see an eclipse
  • live by the sea
  • go on a demonstration
  • sleep in a tent
  • drive a tractor or boat

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity is crucial for practicing the natural switch from present perfect (for general life experience) to past simple (for specific details of that single event). Model the example conversation clearly on the board to highlight the tense change.

title: Mystery Scene: What Has Happened Here?
full_description:
Let's be detectives and use the present perfect to figure out what has happened in a mystery scene.

1. As a class, let's brainstorm clues we might find at a strange scene (e.g., an overturned chair, an open window, a spilled drink, a single glove). Your teacher will write these on the board.

2. Imagine you are detectives who have just arrived. In pairs, look at the clues and make sentences using the present perfect to describe what you think has happened.
   • For example: 'Someone has overturned the chair.' or 'The person has escaped through the window.'

3. Based on the clues, work together to create a short story about the mystery. Be ready to share your theory with the class!

tags.teacher_instruction: The original 'romantic dinner' scenario is outdated and could be uncomfortable for students. This re-theme to a 'mystery/crime scene' is more engaging, flexible, and inclusive. The core grammatical goal (using present perfect to describe the results of past actions) is preserved and even enhanced. You can draw the scene with clues on the board.

title: The Ultimate Checklist: Are We Ready?
full_description:
Let's practice using the present perfect to check if we are ready for a big event.

1. In pairs or small groups, choose one of the following scenarios:
   • Preparing for a big holiday trip
   • Organizing a class party
   • Getting a workshop ready for a project
   • Preparing for a job interview

2. Together, make a checklist of ten important things that need to be done beforehand.

3. Now, role-play the final moments before the event starts. Take turns asking each other questions with the present perfect to check your list.
   • **Example:**
     A: 'Have you packed all the tools?'
     B: 'Yes, I have. Have you charged the batteries?'
     A: 'Oh no, I haven't! Thanks for reminding me.'

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a practical and communicative activity. Write the scenario options on the board. Encourage students to choose a scenario relevant to their vocational studies (e.g., preparing a worksite, setting up for a client, prepping a kitchen for service) as this will increase engagement and allow for specialized vocabulary practice.

title: Possessive Pronoun Challenge: Mine or Yours?
full_description:
Let's practice the difference between possessive adjectives (my, your, her) and possessive pronouns (mine, yours, hers).

**Part 1: Team Challenge**
• Your class will be divided into two teams.
• Your teacher will say a sentence like, 'It's my book.'
• The first team to shout out the correct alternative sentence ('The book is mine!') gets a point.

**Part 2: Memory Test**
• In pairs, try to write down all the sentence pairs from the game from memory.

tags.teacher_instruction:
This is a quick oral drill. Use these prompts for the team challenge:
• It's my pen.
• It's her phone.
• That's my bag.
• It's your car.
• This is our project.
• It's their table.
• This is his laptop.
• That's their dog.

title: Whose Is It Anyway? A Possession Game
full_description:
Let's play a game to practice asking about who owns what.

1. Your teacher will borrow some objects from the class and put them in a bag.

2. In pairs, one person will pick an object without showing it to their partner and start a conversation.

3. Use this conversation as a model:
   • Student A: 'Is this pen yours?'
   • Student B: 'No, it's not mine.'
   • Student A: 'Whose is it then?'
   • Student B: 'I think it's Maria's.'

4. Take turns practicing the conversation with different objects.

tags.teacher_instruction: Before the activity, collect some small, common objects from the students (e.g., a pen, a phone, an eraser, a notebook). Model the target conversation on the board. As students get more confident, you can gradually erase the model to challenge their memory.

title: Comparing Possessions: 'What About Yours?'
full_description:
1. Look at the example question: 'My phone is new; what about yours?'

2. In pairs, change the noun ('phone') and the adjective ('new') to create five new questions of your own. Use items you can see in the classroom.
   • For example: 'My jacket is black; what about yours?' or 'My laptop is old; what about yours?'

3. Find a new partner.

4. Take turns asking and answering your five questions.

title: Don't Disturb Me! Present Continuous Practice
full_description:
1. Your teacher will dictate the beginning of several sentences. Write them down.

2. In pairs, think of a logical ending for each sentence using the present continuous (-ing form). For example, if the teacher says 'Don't listen to him...', you could finish with '...he's telling lies.'

3. After completing the list, create two more of your own sentences that you might use in daily life or at work.

tags.teacher_instruction:
Dictate these sentence starters:
• Don't disturb me; I'm...
• Don't listen to him; he's...
• Quick! Pass the spanner; I'm...
• I can't see you right now; I'm...
• Drink your coffee; it's...
• Leave the video on; I'm...
• Look at that car; it's...
• Shhh! Listen. The baby is...

title: What's Everyone Doing? Describing a Scene
full_description:
1. Look at the scene your teacher is drawing on the board (e.g., a school, a workshop, an office building).

2. As a class, let's identify the different rooms or areas and decide who might be there.

3. In small groups, imagine it's a busy time of day. Discuss and agree on what each person is doing right now. Use the present continuous.
   • For example: 'In the workshop, Karim is fixing an engine.' or 'In the canteen, Lise is listening to a podcast.'

4. Now, think about your own family and friends. In your groups, discuss what you think they are doing right now.

tags.teacher_instruction: Draw a simple cross-section of a building relevant to your students' vocational field (e.g., a workshop, a salon, an office, a kitchen). This makes the context more meaningful than a generic house. Elicit vocabulary for the different areas before starting the group task.

title: Habits vs. Now: A Clothing Conversation
full_description:
Let's practice the difference between the present simple (for habits) and the present continuous (for actions happening now).

Your teacher will start a chain of questions. Listen carefully to decide if the question is about habits ('Do you wear...') or what is happening now ('Are you wearing...?').

• **Example 1 (happening now):**
  Teacher: 'Manuel, are you wearing jeans?'
  Manuel: 'No, I'm not. Ilona, are you wearing jeans?'

• **Example 2 (general habit):**
  Teacher: 'Brigit, do you wear a scarf in winter?'
  Brigit: 'Yes, I do. Peter, do you wear a scarf in winter?'

title: Action Mime Challenge
full_description:
Let's play a game of mime to practice the present continuous.

**Part 1: Teacher's Turn**
• Watch your teacher mime an action. Guess what they are doing by saying, 'You are [verb]-ing.' For example: 'You are driving a car.'

**Part 2: Team Challenge**
• Work in two teams.
• One person from your team will come to the front and mime an action.
• Your team has 30 seconds to guess the action correctly to score a point.

tags.teacher_instruction:
Miming can make some students feel self-conscious, so maintain a fun and supportive atmosphere. The sensitivity warning is included as some students may feel uncomfortable performing in front of the class. For your mime in Part 1, and as suggestions for students, use actions like:
• flying a drone
• watching a tennis match
• scrolling on TikTok
• listening to a podcast
• taking a selfie
• playing a video game

title: Listening to the World: A Soundscape Activity
full_description:
Let's use our ears to practice the present continuous.

**Part 1: What's Happening Outside?**
1. We will all be quiet for two minutes.
2. Listen carefully. Make a note of anything you can hear happening outside the classroom.
3. Use the present continuous to describe the sounds. For example: 'A car is driving by.' or 'Someone is talking loudly on their phone.'

**Part 2: Imagined Location**
• Now, imagine you are in a different, busy location (e.g., at a music festival, in a busy restaurant, at an airport).
• Write a short description of all the things that are happening around you.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a great mindfulness and observation activity. If the area outside your classroom is very quiet, you can play an ambient soundscape video from a resource like YouTube (e.g., 'city sounds', 'restaurant ambience') for Part 1.

title: Digital Postcard: A Holiday Update
full_description:
1. In pairs, imagine you are on holiday in your dream location. You are sitting in a café, and there's a lot going on around you.

2. Write a short social media post or an email to a friend back home.

3. In your message, describe what is happening right now using the present continuous. Include descriptions of:
   • the weather
   • the people you can see
   • what you are eating and drinking
   • your plans for the next day (e.g., 'Tomorrow we are visiting the museum.')

title: Trends and Changes: Your Life and the World
full_description:
Let's use the present continuous to talk about ongoing trends and changes.

**Part 1: Your Life These Days**
• In pairs, tell each other what is happening in your life at the moment. What are you studying? What are you working on? What hobbies are you pursuing?

**Part 2: The World These Days**
• In small groups, discuss what is happening in the wider world. What are some of the big changes or trends you are seeing?
• Talk about some of the following topics:
  • Technology and AI
  • The environment
  • The global economy
  • Culture, fashion, or music
• Agree on a list of the three most important trends and share them with the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original activity included a diary-writing prompt which has been removed to focus on speaking. This activity helps students use the present continuous for ongoing trends, not just actions happening 'right now'. Ensure discussions in Part 2 remain respectful.

title: Weekend Planner: Making Future Arrangements
full_description:
Let's practice using the present continuous to talk about future plans.

1. Copy the weekend planner below. Fill in any THREE of the six time slots with plans. You can be creative! For example: 'testing a new video game' or 'going to a concert'.

   **Saturday | Sunday**
   Morning |
   Afternoon |
   Evening |

2. Now, walk around the room and try to make plans with other students for your empty time slots.

• **Example Conversation:**
  A: 'Are you doing anything on Saturday afternoon?'
  B: 'Yes, I'm meeting a friend for coffee.'
  A: 'Oh, okay. What about Sunday evening?'
  B: 'No, I'm not doing anything then. I'm free.'
  A: 'Would you like to go to the cinema?'
  B: 'Yes, that sounds great!'

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a classic and effective communicative activity. Draw the planner on the board. The original description used 'dairy' instead of 'diary'. This has been corrected. You can suggest students use their actual phone calendars for a modern twist, which makes the role-play more authentic.

title: Always Complaining: Describing Annoying Habits
full_description:
We can use 'always' with the present continuous to talk about repeated, often annoying, habits.

**Part 1: Sharing and Advice**
• In pairs, think of a person you know (IMPORTANT: not someone in this class!) who has an annoying habit. Tell your partner about them. For example: 'My brother is always leaving his wet towels on the floor.'
• Give each other some friendly advice on how to deal with the person.

**Part 2: Guess the Adjective**
• Your teacher will give your pair an adjective that describes a person.
• Write one sentence describing this person's bad habit using 'always + -ing'. For example, for 'lazy': 'He's always leaving his work until the last minute.'
• Read your sentence to the class (without saying the adjective) and see if they can guess the word.

tags.teacher_instruction: This grammar point is nuanced. In Part 1, emphasize that students must not talk about anyone in the class to avoid hurt feelings. The sensitivity warning is included for this reason. For Part 2, distribute these adjectives among the pairs: argumentative, bossy, careless, forgetful, greedy, grumpy, lazy, mean, moody, selfish, unreliable, untidy.

title: Past Participle Game Show
full_description:
Let's test your knowledge of past participles with two fast-paced team games!

**Game 1: Verb Race**
• Work in two teams.
• Your teacher will say a verb in the infinitive (e.g., 'go').
• The first team to shout out the correct past participle ('gone') gets a point. If you're wrong, the other team gets the point.

**Game 2: Noughts and Crosses (Tic-Tac-Toe)**
• Your teacher will draw a Noughts and Crosses grid on the board, with a different verb in each square.
• In your teams, take turns choosing a square.
• To win the square, you must say the past participle of the verb and use it in a correct present perfect sentence. For example, for 'break': 'Broken. I have broken my phone screen.'

tags.teacher_instruction: The original activity contained four different drills. This version combines the most engaging two. For Game 1, have a list of common irregular verbs ready to call out. For Game 2, draw a 3x3 grid and fill it with common irregular verbs like: see, do, be, eat, write, take, give, make, go.

title: Find Someone Who... (Life Experiences)
full_description:
Let's find out about your classmates' life experiences using the present perfect.

1. Your task is to walk around the room and find a different person who has done each thing on the list below.

2. Ask questions starting with 'Have you ever...?' For example: 'Have you ever been to a music festival?'

3. When you find someone who says 'yes', write their name next to the activity.

tags.teacher_instruction:
This is a classic 'Find Someone Who...' mingle activity. Provide students with a worksheet or write this list on the board for them to copy. Use this updated list:
• crash a car (as a passenger or driver)
• ride a horse
• work a night shift
• sing karaoke in public
• go diving
• make bread from scratch
• win a prize or competition
• sleep outside in a tent
• break a bone
• eat caviar
• climb a mountain
• do a bungee jump

title: From Experience to Detail: A Conversation Guide
full_description:
Let's practice how a natural conversation flows from a general experience to specific details.

**Part 1: Pair Conversation**
• In pairs, ask and answer questions starting with 'Have you ever...?' using the topics below.
• If your partner says 'Yes, I have,' ask follow-up questions using the past simple (What...? When...? Where...? Why...?) to find out more.

• **Example:**
  A: 'Have you ever broken a bone?'
  B: 'Yes, I have.'
  A: 'Oh really? What happened?'
  B: 'I broke my arm when I was playing football at school.'

• **Topics:** cut your finger, eat Indian food, see an eclipse, live by the sea, go on a demonstration, do something brave, sleep in a tent, sail a boat, drive a tractor.

**Part 2: Unique Experiences**
• Tell your partner something you've done that you think is unique in the class. Then, guess something they have never done that you think someone else has.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity is excellent for practicing the switch from present perfect (for life experiences) to past simple (for specific details of that experience). Model the example conversation clearly before students begin.

title: Mystery Scene: What Has Happened Here?
full_description:
Let's be detectives and use the present perfect to figure out what has happened based on clues.

**The Situation:**
• Imagine you walk into a room and it's a mess. You are trying to describe what you think has happened based on what you see.

**The Task:**
1. As a class, let's brainstorm some clues you might see. For example: an open window, an empty coffee cup, a knocked-over chair, chocolates on the table, soft music playing.

2. In pairs, look at the clues and make sentences using the present perfect to say what has happened.
   • For example: 'Someone has opened the window.' or 'Someone has made coffee.'

3. Based on the clues, work together to create a short story about the mystery. Was it a thief? Was someone preparing for a date? Be ready to share your theory!

tags.teacher_instruction: The original 'romantic dinner' scenario is outdated and could be uncomfortable for students. This re-theme to a more general 'mystery scene' is more engaging and flexible. The core grammatical goal (using present perfect to describe the results of past actions) is preserved. You can draw the scene with clues on the board or just list them.

title: The Ultimate Checklist: Are We Ready?
full_description:
Let's practice using the present perfect to check if we are ready for a big event.

1. In pairs or small groups, choose one of the following scenarios:
   • Preparing for a holiday trip
   • Organizing a class party
   • Getting ready for a job interview
   • Preparing a workshop for a project

2. Make a checklist of ten important things that need to be done beforehand.

3. Now, imagine it's time to leave or start the event. Role-play checking your list with your partner.
   • **Example:**
     A: 'Have you packed the towels?'
     B: 'Yes, I have. Have you brought the passports?'
     A: 'Oh no, I haven't! I've forgotten them.'

title: Connecting Past Events with the Past Perfect
full_description:
Let's practice connecting a past action that happened *before* another past action, using the past perfect ('had' + past participle).

1. Look at the two columns of sentences below.

2. In pairs, join a sentence from the first column with a logical sentence from the second column.

3. Combine them into one sentence using 'when' and the past perfect for the action that happened first.

• **Example:** The guests left. / We tidied up. -> 'When the guests had left, we tidied up.'

**Column 1 (Happened First)**
• We unpacked our bags.
• I read the book.
• The baby fell asleep.
• Rachael finished her pizza.
• It stopped snowing.

**Column 2 (Happened Second)**
• They went downstairs.
• I lent it to Tom.
• We continued our journey.
• She asked for some coffee.
• We went out.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a structured drill for the past perfect. Write the two columns on the board. The original list was very long and has been shortened and simplified for focus. Ensure students understand that the past perfect action is the one that finished first.

title: Too Late! A Past Perfect Story Game
full_description:
Let's practice using the past perfect to talk about something that already happened when you arrived.

**Part 1: Complete the Sentences**
1. Your teacher will dictate the beginnings of some sentences.
2. In pairs, decide how to finish them using the past perfect. For example: 'When we finally got to the station...' -> '...the train had already left.'

**Part 2: Chain Story**
1. Write two more sentence beginnings like the ones from your teacher (e.g., 'By the time I checked my phone...').
2. Swap your sentences with another pair. Write endings for the sentences you receive.
3. Add one more clause to explain what happened next. For example: 'When we finally got to the station, the train had already left, so we decided to take the bus.'
4. Read your final, long sentence to the class.

tags.teacher_instruction:
Dictate these sentence starters for Part 1:
• When we got to the cinema...
• When he arrived at the meeting...
• When I tried to buy the concert ticket online...
• By the time we arrived at the party...
• When I switched on the TV to watch the match...
• By the time she finally woke up...

title: Guess the Question: A Past Perfect Mystery
full_description:
Let's play a game using the past perfect to explain the reasons for past situations.

1. Your teacher will ask ten 'Why...?' questions about different people.

2. In small groups, write a creative answer for each question using the past perfect. The past perfect explains the reason (the thing that happened *before*).
   • **Example Question:** 'Why was Daniel so happy?'
   • **Example Answer:** 'Because he had just passed his driving test.'

3. After you have written your answers, your teacher will choose a group to read one of their answers aloud.

4. The rest of the class must try to guess the original question!

tags.teacher_instruction:
First, dictate these 'Why...?' questions for students to write down:
1. Why did Rachel feel sick?
2. Why was Jackie so miserable?
3. What did Tom find out when he called?
4. Why was Ken so excited?
5. Where was his sandwich?
6. What did I realize when I got home?
7. Why was the office empty?
8. Why did he feel so guilty?
This game encourages creative thinking while practicing a complex grammar point.

title: Before That Day: Sharing First-Time Experiences
full_description:
Think about a time you did something for the very first time (e.g., travelled to a new country, tried a new food, started a new hobby).

1. On your own, make a few notes about one of your 'first time' experiences.

2. Prepare a sentence using the past perfect structure: 'I had never [done something] before I [did something else].'
   • For example: 'I had never eaten real Italian pizza before I went to Rome.'
   • Or: 'I had never seen a mountain before I moved to Norway.'

3. In pairs or small groups, take turns sharing your sentences and telling your partners a little more about the experience.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity connects the abstract grammar of the past perfect to students' personal lives, making it more memorable. Model the structure clearly on the board before they begin. Encourage a supportive atmosphere where students listen to each other's stories.

title: Looking Back: Describing Changes with the Past Perfect
full_description:
**Part 1: Story Prompts**
• In small groups, read the situations below and continue the story. Use the past perfect ('had changed', 'had painted', etc.) to describe the changes that happened *before* the main event.
• For example: 'When I visited my family, everything was different...' -> '...My mum had thrown out all the old furniture and had painted the walls bright green.'

   1. Josephine was about to arrive for dinner. Everything was ready...
   2. We were ready for our holiday...
   3. When the team arrived back at the airport, the whole city was waiting for them...
   4. He had travelled to the future. The world looked very different...

**Part 2: A Place You Know**
• Think of a real place you know that has changed over time (e.g., your old school, your neighbourhood).
• Write a few sentences about what changes had happened the last time you saw it. For example: 'When I visited my old primary school, they had built a new sports hall.'
• Share your descriptions with your group.

title: What's the Story? Inventing Explanations
full_description:
Let's have some fun inventing creative explanations for strange situations.

1. Work in pairs.

2. Student A: Pretend you saw your partner doing something strange yesterday. Ask them about it. For example: 'I saw you yesterday afternoon. Why were you crying?'

3. Student B: Invent a creative explanation using the past perfect to describe what had happened before. For example: 'I was crying because I had just finished watching a very sad movie.'

4. Take turns asking and explaining using the situations below:
   • ...crying?
   • ...covered in paint?
   • ...laughing hysterically?
   • ...sleeping on a park bench?
   • ...climbing a tree?

tags.teacher_instruction: Write the list of situations on the board. Model one or two examples to show students that the goal is to be creative and practice the grammar structure. This is a light-hearted speaking activity.

title: Past Simple Alphabet Game
full_description:
Let's play a game to practice past simple verbs!

1. In a group of three or four, you will take turns making a sentence in the past simple.

2. The first letter of the main verb must follow the alphabet.

3. If you can't think of a verb for your letter, you are out of the game. The next student continues with the next letter.

• **Example:**
  • Student A: 'I **a**sked a question.'
  • Student B: 'I **b**ought a new phone.'
  • Student C: 'I **c**ame to school late.'
  • Student D: 'I **d**id my homework.'

**Variation for a bigger challenge:** The sentences must connect to form one logical story.

title: Find Your Twin: What Did You Do Yesterday?
full_description:
Let's see if you can find someone in the class who had a similar day to you yesterday.

1. Think of one thing you did yesterday and what time you did it. For example: 'I had breakfast at 8 a.m.' or 'I played video games at 9 p.m.'

2. Walk around the classroom and ask your classmates questions to find someone who did the same thing as you at around the same time.

• **Example conversation:**
  • You: 'What time did you have breakfast yesterday?'
  • Classmate: 'I had breakfast at about 8:30.'

title: What Happened Next? Sequencing Past Events
full_description:
Let's practice telling a short story about what you did in the past.

1. Your teacher will give you some time expressions (e.g., 'last night', 'last weekend').

2. In pairs, ask and answer questions about what you did during that time. For example: 'What did you do last night?'

3. When you answer, describe a sequence of at least three actions. Use sequence markers like 'first', 'then', and 'after that'.
   • **Example:** 'First, I went home and had dinner. Then, I watched a series on Netflix, and after that, I called my friend.'

4. Be ready to tell the class what your partner did.

tags.teacher_instruction: Write these time expressions on the board: 'last night', 'last weekend', 'this morning', 'two days ago'. Also, write the sequence markers: 'First', 'Then', 'Next', 'After that', 'Finally'. Model a full example before students start the pair work.

title: Sentence Relay: A Past Simple Drill
full_description:
Let's do a fast-paced challenge to practice sentence structure.

1. Your teacher will say a sentence and write a 'substitution' word on the board.

2. The first student must repeat the sentence but substitute one word with the new word.

3. The teacher will then provide a new substitution word for the next student.

• **Example:**
  • Teacher says: 'It was very expensive.' (Writes 'good')
  • Student A: 'It was very good.'
  • Teacher writes: 'life'
  • Student B: 'Life was very good.'

tags.teacher_instruction:
This is a mechanical drill good for reinforcing sentence patterns. Keep the pace quick. Here is one of the substitution chains from the original activity:
Base sentence: 'I drove to the park with him.'
Substitutions: shop -> them -> walked -> her -> we

title: Past Tense Story Chain
full_description:
Let's play a memory game and build a story together!

1. The first person starts the story with a short sentence in the past simple.

2. The next person must repeat the first sentence and add a new part to the story.

3. The next person repeats the whole story so far and adds another part.

4. If you forget the sequence or make a mistake, you are out of the game!

• **Example:**
  • Teacher: 'Yesterday I found 100 kroner.'
  • Student A: 'Yesterday I found 100 kroner and I bought a coffee.'
  • Student B: 'Yesterday I found 100 kroner, I bought a coffee, and I met a friend.'

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a classic warm-up or review game. The original '€10 note' has been localized to '100 kroner'. When the story gets too long to remember, you can simply restart it. For a higher-level challenge, you can require each new addition to include an irregular verb.

title: Message Relay Game (Broken Telephone)
full_description:
Let's test our listening skills with a fun game.

**Part 1: Teacher's Message**
1. The class will sit in a circle or a line.
2. Your teacher will whisper a long sentence to the first student.
3. That student will whisper the same sentence to the next person, and so on, until it reaches the last person.
4. The last student says the sentence out loud. Let's see how much it has changed from the original!

**Part 2: Your Message**
1. On your own, write a long sentence that includes at least two past tense verbs.
2. We will sit in a circle and send your messages around the class in the same way.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity is also known as 'Telephone'. For Part 1, use a long, detailed sentence like this: 'We met Samantha and Raymond at the pizza place on the corner and shared a large pepperoni pizza.' Write both the original and final versions on the board to highlight the funny changes.

title: I Don't Believe You! A Storytelling Challenge
full_description:
Let's play a game that mixes storytelling and bluffing.

1. Work in small groups.

2. One person starts telling the group what they did yesterday.

3. After every one or two sentences, the rest of the group must interrupt and shout, 'I don't believe you!'

4. When you are challenged, you must change the last sentence you said and continue your story with the new 'fact'.

• **Example:**
  • Student A: 'I got up at 7:30 and had a shower...'
  • Group: 'I don't believe you!'
  • Student A: 'Okay... I got up at 10:30 and had a coffee. Then I went out for a walk...'
  • Group: 'I don't believe you!'
  • Student A: 'Okay... I read my emails and then I caught the bus to work.'

title: My First Time... Sharing Memories
full_description:
In pairs, share stories about your 'first time' doing some of these things. Tell your partner about the experience.

**Talk about your first:**
• Pet
• Job or summer job
• Friend
• Time living away from home
• Holiday without family
• Memory
• Day at this school
• Car or moped
• Flight on a plane

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a personal sharing activity. The list has been curated to be appropriate for this age group. Write the prompts on the board. Remind students that they only need to talk about topics they feel comfortable sharing. The goal is fluency and storytelling practice in the past simple.

title: When Was the Last Time You...?
full_description:
Let's practice asking and answering questions about recent experiences.

**Part 1: Last Time Activities**
• In pairs, ask each other questions about the last time you did these things. Give some extra details in your answer.
• For example:
  A: 'When did you last go to the cinema?'
  B: 'The last time I went to the cinema was two weeks ago. I saw the new Dune movie.'

• Activities: eat at a restaurant, take exercise, travel by boat, have a cold, cook a meal, laugh really hard, send an important email, clean your room, tell a lie, stay up all night.

**Part 2: Follow-up Questions**
• In pairs, ask and answer questions beginning with 'What was the last thing you...?'
• After each answer, ask a follow-up question.
• For example:
  A: 'What was the last thing you bought online?'
  B: 'A new pair of headphones.'
  A: 'How much did you pay for them?'
  B: 'They cost about 500 kroner.'

• Verbs: buy, make, break, eat, sell, write, drink, learn, find, read, throw away.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original currency (€) has been localized to kroner.

title: First and Last Time: A Verb Game
full_description:
Let's play a competitive game to practice the past simple.

1. Work in two teams.

2. Your teacher will prepare a pile of cards with verbs on them for your team.

3. Take turns picking up a verb card. You must make a correct sentence with that verb, beginning with 'The first time I...' or 'The last time I...'.

4. If your sentence is grammatically correct, your team keeps the card and gets a point.

5. If the other team finds a mistake in your sentence, they can challenge you. If they are right, they steal your card and get the point!

6. The team with the most cards at the end is the winner.

tags.teacher_instruction: Before the game, have students help you brainstorm 20-30 common regular and irregular verbs to write on the slips of paper. This makes the game more student-centered.

title: A Day in the Life: Sequencing a Story
full_description:
Let's work together to create a story about a person's typical day.

**Part 1: Order the Actions**
• In pairs, look at the list of phrases below. First, change the verbs to the past simple. Then, arrange the phrases in a logical order to describe someone's morning.
• Use words like 'and', 'then', and 'after that' to connect the sentences.

   (Actions: wake up, get up, make coffee, have a shower, check phone, get dressed, leave the house, drive to work/school)

**Part 2: Ask and Answer**
• Write one question about each sentence in your story (e.g., 'What time did he wake up?').
• Join with another pair. Ask and answer your questions.

**Part 3: Continue the Story**
• As a group of four, continue the story of the person's day. What happened at work or school? What did they do in the evening? Choose one person to read your finished story to the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original list of actions has been modernized and simplified for clarity.

title: Cause and Effect: Connecting Past Actions
full_description:
Let's practice connecting two events in the past using the word 'when'.

**Part 1: Sentence Building**
1. Your teacher will dictate pairs of short sentences. For example: 'The shark appeared. They panicked.'
2. Rewrite them as one single sentence in the past tense, starting with 'when'. For example: 'When the shark appeared, they panicked.'

**Part 2: Create Your Own**
1. On your own, write two pairs of simple cause-and-effect sentences about your own life.
2. Swap your sentences with a partner. Join the sentences you receive using 'when' and then pass them back.

tags.teacher_instruction:
For Part 1, dictate these sentence pairs for students to join:
1. She reads the letter. She throws it in the bin.
2. The bell rings. They run out of the classroom.
3. The rain stops. We go outside.
4. I get home. I switch on the radio.

title: Mine or Yours? Possessive Pronoun Drill
full_description:
Let's practice the difference between possessive adjectives (my, your, her) and possessive pronouns (mine, yours, hers).

**Part 1: Class Drill**
• Listen to the sentence your teacher says. Your job is to shout out the same sentence, but using a possessive pronoun.
• For example:
  Teacher: 'It's my book.'
  Class: 'The book is mine!'

**Part 2: Pair Practice**
• In pairs, try to write down all the sentence pairs from the drill from memory.

tags.teacher_instruction:
This is a quick oral drill. Use these prompts for Part 1:
• It's my pen.
• It's her phone.
• That's my bag.
• It's your car.
• This is our project.
• It's their baby.
• This is his house.
• That's their dog.

title: Whose Is It? Object Game
full_description:
Let's play a game to practice asking and answering questions about who owns what.

1. Your teacher will borrow an object from a student and show it to the class.

2. In pairs, practice this conversation:
   • Student A: 'Is this yours?'
   • Student B: 'No, it's not mine.'
   • Student A: 'Whose is it then?'
   • Student B: 'I think it's his/hers/Maria's.'

3. Take turns picking an object and having a similar conversation with your partner.

tags.teacher_instruction: Start by collecting some small, common objects from the students (e.g., a pen, a phone, an eraser, a notebook). Model the exchange on the board first, then gradually erase it as students become more confident.

title: Comparing Ours: 'What About Yours?'
full_description:
1. Look at the example question: 'My shoes are brown; what about yours?'

2. In pairs, change the noun ('shoes') and the adjective ('brown') to create five new questions of your own.
   • For example: 'My phone is new; what about yours?' or 'My jacket is black; what about yours?'

3. Find a new partner.

4. Take turns asking and answering the five questions you wrote.

title: Don't Disturb Me! Present Continuous Practice
full_description:
Let's practice using the present continuous to talk about actions happening right now.

1. Your teacher will dictate the beginning of some sentences.

2. Write them down and, in pairs, think of a suitable ending using the present continuous (-ing form).

3. After you finish the list, think of two more sentences that are useful for you in your daily life or at your workplace.

tags.teacher_instruction:
Dictate these sentence starters for students to complete:
• Please turn the music down; I'm...
• Don't listen to him; he's...
• Quick! Pass me the tool; I'm...
• I can't talk right now; I'm...
• Be careful! The coffee is...
• Leave the video on; I'm...
• Look at that car; it's...
• Shhh! Listen. The baby is...

title: What's Everyone Doing? Describing a Scene
full_description:
Let's describe a busy scene using the present continuous.

1. Look at the picture your teacher is drawing on the board (e.g., a school, a workshop, a salon).

2. As a class, let's identify the different rooms or areas and decide who is in them.

3. In small groups, imagine it's a busy time of day. Discuss and agree on what each person is doing right now.
   • For example: 'In the workshop, Karim is fixing an engine.' or 'In the classroom, Lise is listening to a podcast.'

4. Now, think about your own family and friends. In your groups, discuss what you think they are doing right now.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity is excellent for practicing the present continuous in context. To make it more relevant for vocational students, draw their school, a workshop, a salon, or an office building instead of a generic house. Elicit vocabulary for the different areas before starting the main task.

title: First and Last Time: A Verb Game
full_description:
Let's play a competitive game to practice the past simple.

1. Work in two teams.

2. Your teacher will prepare a pile of cards with verbs on them for your team.

3. Take turns picking up a verb card. You must make a correct sentence with that verb, beginning with 'The first time I...' or 'The last time I...'.

4. If your sentence is grammatically correct, your team keeps the card and gets a point.

5. If the other team finds a mistake in your sentence, they can challenge you. If they are right, they steal your card and get the point!

6. The team with the most verbs at the end is the winner.

tags.teacher_instruction: Before the game, have students help you brainstorm 20-30 common regular and irregular verbs to write on the slips of paper. This makes the game more student-centered.

title: A Day in the Life: Sequencing a Story
full_description:
Let's work together to create a story about a person's typical day.

**Part 1: Order the Actions**
• In pairs, look at the list of phrases below. First, change the verbs to the past simple. Then, arrange the phrases in a logical order to describe someone's morning.
• Use words like 'and', 'then', and 'after that' to connect the sentences.

   (Actions: wake up, get up, make coffee, have a shower, check phone, get dressed, leave the house, drive to work/school)

**Part 2: Ask and Answer**
• Write one question about each sentence in your story (e.g., 'What time did he wake up?').
• Join with another pair. Ask and answer your questions.

**Part 3: Continue the Story**
• As a group of four, continue the story of the person's day. What happened at work or school? What did they do in the evening? Choose one person to read your finished story to the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original list of actions has been modernized and simplified for clarity.

**Part 2: Create Your Own**
1. On your own, write two pairs of simple cause-and-effect sentences about your own life.
2. Swap your sentences with a partner. Join the sentences you receive using 'when' and then pass them back.

title: Pronoun Drill: Mine vs. My
full_description:
**Part 1: Class Drill**
• Listen to the sentence your teacher says. Your job is to quickly say the same thing using a possessive pronoun.
• For example:
  Teacher: 'It's my book.'
  Class: 'The book is mine!'

**Part 2: Memory Challenge**
• In pairs, try to write down all the sentence pairs from the drill from memory.

tags.teacher_instruction:
This is a quick oral drill. The original list included 'That is my man', which has been removed. Use these modernized prompts for Part 1:
• It's my pen.
• It's her phone.
• That's my bag.
• It's your car.
• This is our project.
• It's their table.
• This is his laptop.
• That's their dog.

title: Whose Is It Anyway? A Possession Game
full_description:
Let's play a game to practice asking about who owns what.

1. Your teacher will borrow some small objects from the class.

2. In pairs, one person will pick an object and ask their partner about it.

3. Use this conversation as a model:
   • Student A: (holding a pen) 'Is this yours?'
   • Student B: 'No, it's not mine.'
   • Student A: 'Whose is it then?'
   • Student B: 'I think it's his/hers/Maria's.'

4. Take turns practicing the conversation.

tags.teacher_instruction: Before the activity, collect some small, common objects from the students (e.g., a pen, a phone, an eraser, a notebook) and put them in a bag or box. Model the target conversation on the board. As students get more confident, you can gradually erase the model to challenge their memory.

title: Comparing Possessions: 'What About Yours?'
full_description:
1. Look at the example question: 'My phone is new; what about yours?'

2. In pairs, change the noun ('phone') and the adjective ('new') to create five new questions of your own. Use items you can see in the classroom.
