   • For example: 'My jacket is black; what about yours?' or 'My laptop is old; what about yours?'

3. Find a new partner.

4. Take turns asking and answering your five questions.

title: Present Continuous Sentence Completion
full_description:
1. Your teacher will dictate the beginning of several sentences. Write them down.

2. In pairs, think of a logical ending for each sentence using the present continuous (-ing form). For example, if the teacher says 'Don't disturb me...', you could finish with '...I'm working on something important.'

3. After completing the list, create two more of your own sentences that you might use in daily life.

tags.teacher_instruction:
Dictate these sentence starters:
• Don't disturb me; I'm...
• Don't listen to him; he's...
• Quick! Pass the spanner; I'm...
• I can't talk right now; I'm...
• Drink your coffee; it's...
• Leave the video on; I'm...
• Look at that car; it's...
• Shhh! Listen. The baby is...

title: Describing a Busy Scene: What's Everyone Doing?
full_description:
1. Look at the picture your teacher is drawing on the board (e.g., a school, a workshop, an office building).

2. As a class, let's identify the different rooms or areas and decide who might be there.

3. In small groups, imagine it's a busy time of day. Discuss and agree on what each person is doing right now. Use the present continuous.
   • For example: 'In the workshop, Karim is fixing an engine.' or 'In the canteen, Lise is drinking a coffee.'

4. Now, think about your own family and friends. In your groups, discuss what you think they are doing right now.

tags.teacher_instruction: To make it more relevant for vocational students, you could draw their school, a workshop, a salon, or an office building instead of a house. This makes the context more meaningful. Elicit vocabulary for the different areas before starting the group task.

title: Habits vs. Now: A Clothing Conversation
full_description:
Let's practice the difference between the present simple (for habits and general truths) and the present continuous (for actions happening now).

Your teacher will start a chain of questions. Listen carefully to decide if the question is about habits ('Do you wear...') or what is happening now ('Are you wearing...?').

• **Example 1 (happening now):**
  Teacher: 'Manuel, are you wearing jeans?'
  Manuel: 'No, I'm not. Ilona, are you wearing jeans?'

• **Example 2 (general habit):**
  Teacher: 'Brigit, do you wear a scarf in winter?'
  Brigit: 'Yes, I do. Peter, do you wear a scarf in winter?'

title: Action Mime Challenge
full_description:
Let's play a game of mime to practice the present continuous.

**Part 1: Teacher's Turn**
• Watch your teacher mime an action. Guess what they are doing by saying, 'You are [verb]-ing.' For example: 'You are driving a car.'

**Part 2: Team Challenge**
• Work in two teams.
• One person from your team will come to the front and mime an action.
• Your team has 30 seconds to guess the action correctly to score a point.

tags.teacher_instruction:
Miming can make some students feel self-conscious, so maintain a fun and supportive atmosphere. The sensitivity warning is included as some students may feel uncomfortable performing in front of the class. For your mime in Part 1, and as suggestions for students, use this updated list of actions:
• flying a drone
• watching a tennis match
• scrolling on TikTok
• listening to a podcast
• taking a selfie
• playing a video game

title: Listening to the World: A Soundscape Activity
full_description:
**Part 1: What's Happening Outside?**
1. We will all be quiet for two minutes.
2. Listen carefully. Make a note of anything you can hear happening outside the classroom.
3. Use the present continuous to describe the sounds. For example: 'A car is driving by.' or 'Someone is talking loudly on their phone.'

**Part 2: Imagined Location**
• Now, imagine you are in a different, busy location (e.g., at a music festival, in a busy restaurant, at an airport).
• Write a short description of all the things that are happening around you.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a great mindfulness and observation activity. If the area outside your classroom is very quiet, you can play an ambient soundscape video from a resource like YouTube (e.g., 'city sounds', 'restaurant ambience') for Part 1.

title: Digital Postcard: A Holiday Update
full_description:
1. In pairs, imagine you are on holiday in your dream location. You are sitting in a café, and there's a lot going on around you.

2. Write a short social media post or an email to a friend back home.

3. In your message, describe what is happening right now using the present continuous. Include descriptions of:
   • the weather
   • the people you can see
   • what you are eating and drinking
   • your plans for the next day (e.g., 'Tomorrow we are visiting the museum.')

title: Trends and Changes: Your Life and the World
full_description:
Let's use the present continuous to talk about ongoing trends and changes.

**Part 1: Your Life These Days**
• In pairs, tell each other what is happening in your life at the moment. What are you studying? What are you working on? What hobbies are you pursuing?

**Part 2: The World These Days**
• In small groups, discuss what is happening in the wider world. What are some of the big changes or trends you are seeing?
• Talk about some of the following topics:
  • Technology and AI
  • The environment
  • The global economy
  • Culture, fashion, or music
• Agree on a list of the three most important trends and share them with the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original activity included a diary-writing prompt which has been removed to focus on speaking. This activity helps students use the present continuous for ongoing trends, not just actions happening 'right now'. Ensure discussions in Part 2 remain respectful.

title: The Weekend Planner: Making Future Plans
full_description:
Let's practice using the present continuous to talk about future plans.

1. Draw a simple weekend planner with slots for Saturday morning, afternoon, evening, and Sunday morning, afternoon, evening.

2. Fill in any THREE of the six slots with plans you have. You can be creative! For example: 'testing a new video game' or 'going to a concert'.

3. Now, walk around the room and try to make plans with other students to fill your THREE empty slots.

• **Example Conversation:**
  A: 'What are you doing on Saturday afternoon?'
  B: 'I'm meeting a friend for coffee.'
  A: 'Okay. Are you doing anything on Sunday evening?'
  B: 'No, I'm not doing anything. I'm free!'
  A: 'Would you like to see a movie?'

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a classic communicative activity. The original description used 'dairy' instead of 'diary'. This has been corrected. You can suggest students use their actual phone calendars for a modern twist, which makes the role-play more authentic.

title: Always Complaining: Describing Annoying Habits
full_description:
We can use 'always' with the present continuous to complain about repeated, annoying habits.

**Part 1: Sharing & Advice**
• In pairs, think of a person you know (IMPORTANT: not someone in this class!) who has an annoying habit. Tell your partner about them using the 'always + -ing' structure. For example: 'My brother is always leaving his dirty dishes in the sink.'
• Give each other some friendly advice.

**Part 2: Guess the Adjective**
• Your teacher will give your pair an adjective.
• Write one sentence describing a person with this quality, using 'always + -ing'.
• Read your sentence to the class (don't say the adjective!) and see if they can guess the word.

tags.teacher_instruction: It is very important to stress that students must not talk about anyone in the class to avoid hurt feelings. The sensitivity warning is included for this reason. For Part 2, distribute these adjectives among the pairs: argumentative, bossy, careless, forgetful, greedy, grumpy, lazy, mean, moody, selfish, unreliable, untidy.

title: Present Perfect Game Show
full_description:
Let's test your knowledge of past participles with two fast-paced team games!

**Game 1: Verb Race**
• Work in two teams.
• Your teacher will say a verb in the infinitive (e.g., 'go').
• The first team to shout out the correct past participle ('gone') gets a point. If you're wrong, the other team gets the point.

**Game 2: Noughts and Crosses (Tic-Tac-Toe)**
• The teacher will draw a 3x3 grid on the board with a different verb in each square.
• Take turns choosing a square for your team.
• To win the square, you must say the past participle and use it in a correct present perfect sentence. For example, for 'take': 'Taken. I have taken the bus today.'

tags.teacher_instruction: The original activity contained four different drills. This version combines the two most engaging. For Game 1, have a list of common irregular verbs ready to call out. For Game 2, draw the grid and fill it with verbs your students find difficult, like: see, do, be, eat, write, give, make, go, break.

title: Class Survey: Have You Ever...?
full_description:
Let's find out about your classmates' life experiences!

1. Your task is to walk around the room and find a different person who has done each thing on the list below.

2. Ask questions using the present perfect: 'Have you ever...?'

3. When someone answers 'yes', write their name next to the activity on your paper.

tags.teacher_instruction:
This is a classic 'Find Someone Who...' mingle activity. Provide the students with this updated list of experiences:
• crash a car (as a passenger or driver)
• ride a horse
• work a night shift
• sing karaoke in public
• go diving
• make bread from scratch
• win a prize or competition
• sleep outside in a tent
• break a bone
• eat caviar
• climb a mountain
• build your own PC

title: From Experience to Detail: A Conversation Guide
full_description:
**Part 1: Pair Conversation**
• In pairs, ask and answer questions starting with 'Have you ever...?' using the topics below.
• If your partner says 'Yes, I have,' ask follow-up questions using the past simple (What...? When...? Where...? Why...?) to find out more.

• **Example:**
  A: 'Have you ever broken a bone?'
  B: 'Yes, I have.'
  A: 'Oh really? What happened?'
  B: 'I broke my arm when I was playing football at school.'

• **Topics:** cut your finger, eat Indian food, see an eclipse, live by the sea, go on a demonstration, do something brave, sleep in a tent, sail a boat, drive a tractor.

**Part 2: Unique Experiences**
• Tell your partner something you've done that you think is unique in the class. Then, guess something they have never done that you think someone else has.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity is excellent for practicing the switch from present perfect (for life experiences) to past simple (for specific details of that experience). Model the example conversation clearly before students begin.

title: Mystery Scene: What Has Happened Here?
full_description:
Let's be detectives and use the present perfect to figure out what has happened based on clues.

**The Situation:**
• Imagine you walk into a room and it's a mess. You are trying to describe what you think has happened based on what you see.

**The Task:**
1. As a class, let's brainstorm some clues you might see. For example: an open window, an empty coffee cup, a knocked-over chair, chocolates on the table, soft music playing.

2. In pairs, look at the clues and make sentences using the present perfect to say what has happened.
   • For example: 'Someone has opened the window.' or 'Someone has made coffee.'

3. Based on the clues, work together to create a short story about the mystery. Was it a thief? Was someone preparing for a date? Be ready to share your theory!

tags.teacher_instruction: The original 'romantic dinner' scenario is outdated and could be uncomfortable for students. This re-theme to a more general 'mystery scene' is more engaging and flexible. The core grammatical goal (using present perfect to describe the results of past actions) is preserved. You can draw the scene with clues on the board or just list them.

title: The Ultimate Checklist: Are We Ready?
full_description:
Let's practice using the present perfect to check if we are ready for a big event.

1. In pairs or small groups, choose one of the following scenarios:
   • Preparing for a holiday trip
   • Organizing a class party
   • Getting ready for a job interview
   • Preparing a workshop for a project

2. Make a checklist of ten important things that need to be done beforehand.

3. Now, imagine it's time to leave or start the event. Role-play checking your list with your partner.
   • **Example:**
     A: 'Have you packed the towels?'
     B: 'Yes, I have. Have you brought the passports?'
     A: 'Oh no, I haven't! I've forgotten them.'

tags.teacher_instruction: Encouraging students to choose a scenario relevant to their vocational studies (e.g., preparing a worksite, setting up for a client, prepping a kitchen for service) will increase engagement and allow for specialized vocabulary practice.

title: Interrupted Actions: A Sentence-Building Game
full_description:
Let's practice connecting two past actions using 'when'.

1. Your class will be split into two groups.

2. One group will write fifteen nouns on separate pieces of paper (e.g., 'phone', 'TV', 'pizza'). The other group will do the same.

3. Swap your pile of words with the other group.

4. Take turns picking a piece of paper from the pile. You must use that word to make a sentence about what you were doing when something else happened. For example, if you pick 'TV':
   • Student A: 'I was watching TV when the power went out.'

5. Another student in the group must then ask a follow-up question about what you did next:
   • Student B: 'What did you do when the power went out?'
   • Student A: 'When the power went out, I lit some candles.'

tags.teacher_instruction: The goal is to practice the structure: Past Continuous + 'when' + Past Simple. Encourage students to write modern, relevant nouns on their pieces of paper (e.g., 'TikTok', 'game', 'podcast', 'Snapchat').

title: My Timeline: Sharing Life Events
full_description:
**Part 1: Analyse an Example**
• Look at the example timeline. In pairs, write a few sentences about the person's life. For example: 'While he was living in Bergen, he met his girlfriend.' or 'When his parents moved, he started at a new school.'

**Part 2: Create Your Own Timeline**
1. Draw your own lifeline on a piece of paper. Add 4-5 important events and the years they happened.
2. You don't have to share very personal information; you can focus on school, hobbies, travel, or other interests.

**Part 3: Share with a Partner**
• Exchange your timeline with a partner. Ask each other questions to get more information and write sentences about your partner's life, just like you did in Part 1.

tags.teacher_instruction:
Provide this simplified example timeline on the board:
Born in Bergen, 2008 | Moved to Oslo, 2018 | Started VG1, 2024
Met best friend, 2012 | Started playing guitar, 2020 | Got summer job, 2025
Remind students that this is a language practice activity, and they should only share what they feel comfortable with. The sensitivity warning is set to true as lifelines can bring up personal topics.

title: Accident Report: Role-Play and Writing
full_description:
Let's investigate an accident and practice reporting what happened.

**The Situation:**
Your teacher will read a description of a traffic accident involving a lorry and an e-scooter rider.

**The Role-Play:**
1. Work in groups of four. Each person has a different role:
   • **Student A:** The lorry driver.
   • **Student B:** The e-scooter rider.
   • **Student C:** An independent witness who saw everything.
   • **Student D:** The police officer who asks questions to understand what happened.
2. Role-play the discussion at the scene of the accident. The driver and rider blame each other.

**The Report:**
1. After the role-play, write a short police report from YOUR character's point of view.
2. Describe what was happening, what you saw, and what happened next.
3. Take turns reading your report to your group.

tags.teacher_instruction:
Begin by dictating this modernized accident description:
'Yesterday morning at 8:30, there was an accident between a lorry and an e-scooter at a busy intersection. It was raining, but visibility was good. The lorry was turning right, and the e-scooter rider was going straight. Neither person was seriously injured, but the e-scooter was broken. The driver and the rider both have to make a report. They blame each other.'
This activity is excellent for practicing past simple vs. past continuous in a practical context.

title: Sentence Matching: Using the Past Perfect
full_description:
Let's practice connecting a past action that happened *before* another past action, using the past perfect ('had' + past participle).

1. Look at the two columns of sentences below.

2. In pairs, join a sentence from the first column with a logical sentence from the second column.

3. Combine them into one sentence using 'when' and the past perfect for the action that happened first.

• **Example:** The guests left. / We tidied up. -> 'When the guests had left, we tidied up.'

**Column 1 (Happened First)**
• We unpacked our bags.
• I read the book.
• The baby fell asleep.
• Rachael finished her pizza.
• It stopped snowing.

**Column 2 (Happened Second)**
• They went downstairs.
• I lent it to Tom.
• We continued our journey.
• She asked for some coffee.
• We went out.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a structured drill for the past perfect. The original list was very long and has been shortened and simplified for focus. Write the two columns on the board and check answers as a class.

title: Too Late! Finishing Stories with the Past Perfect
full_description:
**Part 1: Complete the Sentences**
1. Your teacher will dictate the beginnings of some sentences.
2. In pairs, decide how to finish them using the past perfect. For example: 'When we finally got to the station...' -> '...the train had already left.'

**Part 2: Chain Story**
1. Write two more sentence beginnings like the ones from your teacher (e.g., 'By the time I checked my phone...').
2. Swap your sentences with another pair. Write endings for the sentences you receive.
3. Add one more sentence to explain what happened next. For example: 'When we got to the station, the train had already left, so we decided to take the bus.'

tags.teacher_instruction:
Dictate these sentence starters for Part 1:
• When we got to the cinema...
• When he arrived at the meeting...
• When I tried to buy the concert ticket online...
• By the time we arrived at the party...
• When I switched on the TV to watch the match...
• By the time she finally woke up...

title: Why Did It Happen? A Past Perfect Guessing Game
full_description:
Let's play a game using the past perfect to explain the reasons for past situations.

1. Your teacher will ask ten 'Why...?' questions about different people.

2. In small groups, write a creative answer for each question using the past perfect. The past perfect explains the reason (the thing that happened *before*).
   • **Example Question:** 'Why was Daniel so happy?'
   • **Example Answer:** 'Because he had just passed his driving test.'

3. After you have written your answers, your teacher will choose a group to read one of their answers aloud.

4. The rest of the class must try to guess the original question!

tags.teacher_instruction:
First, dictate these 'Why...?' questions for students to write down:
1. Why did Rachel feel sick?
2. Why was Jackie so miserable?
3. What did Tom find out when he called?
4. Why was Ken so excited?
5. Where was his sandwich?
6. What did I realise when I got home?
7. Why was the office empty?
8. Why did he feel so guilty?
This game encourages creative thinking while practicing a complex grammar point.

title: Before That Day: Sharing First-Time Experiences
full_description:
Think about a time you did something for the very first time (e.g., travelled to a new country, tried a new food, started a new hobby).

1. On your own, make a few notes about one of your 'first time' experiences.

2. Prepare a sentence using the past perfect structure: 'I had never [done something] before I [did something else].'
   • For example: 'I had never eaten real Italian pizza before I went to Rome.'
   • Or: 'I had never seen a mountain before I moved to Norway.'

3. In pairs or small groups, take turns sharing your sentences and telling your partners a little more about the experience.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity connects the abstract grammar of the past perfect to students' personal lives, making it more memorable. Model the structure clearly on the board before they begin. Encourage a supportive atmosphere where students listen to each other's stories.

title: Looking Back: Describing Changes with the Past Perfect
full_description:
**Part 1: Story Prompts**
• In small groups, read the situations below and continue the story. Use the past perfect ('had changed', 'had painted', etc.) to describe the changes that happened *before* the main event.
• For example: 'When I visited my family, everything was different...' -> '...My mum had thrown out all the old furniture and had painted the walls bright green.'

   1. Josephine was about to arrive for dinner. Everything was ready...
   2. We were ready for our holiday...
   3. When the team arrived back at the airport, the whole city was waiting for them...
   4. He had travelled to the future. The world looked very different...

**Part 2: A Place You Know**
• Think of a real place you know that has changed over time (e.g., your old school, your neighbourhood).
• Write a few sentences about what changes had happened the last time you saw it. For example: 'When I visited my old primary school, they had built a new sports hall.'
• Share your descriptions with your group.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity has been streamlined to focus on the writing and speaking tasks, removing a more complex narrative element from the original. Encourage students to be descriptive and creative.

title: What's the Story? Inventing Explanations
full_description:
Let's have some fun inventing creative explanations for strange situations.

1. Work in pairs.

2. Student A: Pretend you saw your partner doing something strange yesterday. Ask them about it. For example: 'I saw you yesterday afternoon. Why were you crying?'

3. Student B: Invent a creative explanation using the past perfect to describe what had happened before. For example: 'I was crying because I had just finished watching a very sad movie.'

4. Take turns asking and explaining using the situations below:
   • ...crying?
   • ...covered in paint?
   • ...laughing hysterically?
   • ...sleeping on a park bench?
   • ...climbing a tree?

tags.teacher_instruction: Write the list of situations on the board. Model one or two examples to show students that the goal is to be creative and practice the grammar structure. This is a light-hearted speaking activity.

title: Past Simple Alphabet Game
full_description:
Let's play a game to practice past simple verbs!

1. In a group of three or four, you will take turns making a sentence in the past simple.

2. The first letter of the main verb must follow the alphabet.

3. If you can't think of a verb for your letter, you are out of the game. The next student continues with the next letter.

• **Example:**
  • Student A: 'I **a**sked a question.'
  • Student B: 'I **b**ought a new phone.'
  • Student C: 'I **c**ame to school late.'
  • Student D: 'I **d**id my homework.'

**Variation for a bigger challenge:** The sentences must connect to form one logical story.

title: Find Your Twin: What Did You Do Yesterday?
full_description:
Let's see if you can find someone in the class who had a similar day to you yesterday.

1. Think of one thing you did yesterday and what time you did it. For example: 'I had breakfast at 8 a.m.' or 'I played video games at 9 p.m.'

2. Walk around the classroom and ask your classmates questions to find someone who did the same thing as you at around the same time.

• **Example conversation:**
  • You: 'What time did you have breakfast yesterday?'
  • Classmate: 'I had breakfast at about 8:30.'

title: What Happened Next? Sequencing Past Events
full_description:
Let's practice telling a short story about what you did in the past.

1. Your teacher will give you some time expressions (e.g., 'last night', 'last weekend').

2. In pairs, ask and answer questions about what you did during that time. For example: 'What did you do last night?'

3. When you answer, describe a sequence of at least three actions. Use sequence markers like 'first', 'then', and 'after that'.
   • **Example:** 'First, I went home and had dinner. Then, I watched a series on Netflix, and after that, I called my friend.'

4. Be ready to tell the class what your partner did.

tags.teacher_instruction: Write these time expressions on the board: 'last night', 'last weekend', 'this morning', 'two days ago'. Also, write the sequence markers: 'First', 'Then', 'Next', 'After that', 'Finally'. Model a full example before students start the pair work.

title: Sentence Relay: A Past Simple Drill
full_description:
Let's do a fast-paced challenge to practice sentence structure.

1. Your teacher will say a sentence and write a 'substitution' word on the board.

2. The first student must repeat the sentence but substitute one word with the new word.

3. The teacher will then provide a new substitution word for the next student.

• **Example:**
  • Teacher says: 'It was very expensive.' (Writes 'good')
  • Student A: 'It was very good.'
  • Teacher writes: 'life'
  • Student B: 'Life was very good.'

tags.teacher_instruction:
This is a mechanical drill good for reinforcing sentence patterns. Keep the pace quick. Here is one of the substitution chains from the original activity to use as a model:
Base sentence: 'I drove to the park with him.'
Substitutions: shop -> them -> walked -> her -> we

title: Past Tense Story Chain
full_description:
Let's play a memory game and build a story together!

1. The first person starts the story with a short sentence in the past simple.

2. The next person must repeat the first sentence and add a new part to the story.

3. The next person repeats the whole story so far and adds another part.

4. If you forget the sequence or make a mistake, you are out of the game!

• **Example:**
  • Teacher: 'Yesterday I found 100 kroner.'
  • Student A: 'Yesterday I found 100 kroner and I bought a coffee.'
  • Student B: 'Yesterday I found 100 kroner, I bought a coffee, and I met a friend.'

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a classic warm-up or review game. The original '€10 note' has been localized to '100 kroner'. When the story gets too long to remember, you can simply restart it. For a higher-level challenge, you can require each new addition to include an irregular verb.

title: Message Relay Game (Broken Telephone)
full_description:
Let's test our listening skills with a fun game.

**Part 1: Teacher's Message**
1. The class will sit in a circle or a line.
2. Your teacher will whisper a long sentence to the first student.
3. That student will whisper the same sentence to the next person, and so on, until it reaches the last person.
4. The last student says the sentence out loud. Let's see how much it has changed from the original!

**Part 2: Your Message**
1. On your own, write a long sentence that includes at least two past tense verbs.
2. We will sit in a circle and send your messages around the class in the same way.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity is also known as 'Telephone'. For Part 1, use a long, detailed sentence like this: 'We met Samantha and Raymond at the pizza place on the corner and shared a large pepperoni pizza.' Write both the original and final versions on the board to highlight the funny changes.

title: I Don't Believe You! A Storytelling Challenge
full_description:
Let's play a game that mixes storytelling and bluffing.

1. Work in small groups.

2. One person starts telling the group what they did yesterday.

3. After every one or two sentences, the rest of the group must interrupt and shout, 'I don't believe you!'

4. When you are challenged, you must change the last sentence you said and continue your story with the new 'fact'.

• **Example:**
  • Student A: 'I got up at 7:30 and had a shower...'
  • Group: 'I don't believe you!'
  • Student A: 'Okay... I got up at 10:30 and had a coffee. Then I went out for a walk...'
  • Group: 'I don't believe you!'
  • Student A: 'Okay... I read my emails and then I caught the bus to work.'

tags.teacher_instruction: The goal of this activity is fluency and creative thinking, not telling the truth. Encourage students to become more and more imaginative as the game progresses.

title: My First Time... Sharing Memories
full_description:
In pairs, share stories about your 'first time' doing some of these things. Tell your partner about the experience.

**Talk about your first:**
• Pet
• Job or summer job
• Friend
• Time living away from home
• Holiday without family
• Memory
• Day at this school
• Car or moped
• Flight on a plane

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a personal sharing activity. The list has been curated to be appropriate for this age group. Write the prompts on the board. Remind students that they only need to talk about topics they feel comfortable sharing. The goal is fluency and storytelling practice in the past simple.

title: When Was the Last Time You...?
full_description:
Let's practice asking and answering questions about recent experiences.

**Part 1: Last Time Activities**
• In pairs, ask each other questions about the last time you did these things. Give some extra details in your answer.
• For example:
  A: 'When did you last go to the cinema?'
  B: 'The last time I went to the cinema was two weeks ago. I saw the new Dune movie.'

• Activities: eat at a restaurant, take exercise, travel by boat, have a cold, cook a meal, laugh really hard, send an important email, clean your room, tell a lie, stay up all night.

**Part 2: Follow-up Questions**
• In pairs, ask and answer questions beginning with 'What was the last thing you...?'
• After each answer, ask a follow-up question.
• For example:
  A: 'What was the last thing you bought online?'
  B: 'A new pair of headphones.'
  A: 'How much did you pay for them?'
  B: 'They cost about 500 kroner.'

• Verbs: buy, make, break, eat, sell, write, drink, learn, find, read, throw away.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original currency (€) has been localized to kroner. This is a straightforward pair work activity to encourage fluent use of the past simple.

title: First and Last Time: A Verb Game
full_description:
Let's play a competitive game to practice the past simple.

1. Work in two teams.

2. Your teacher will prepare a pile of cards with verbs on them for your team.

3. Take turns picking up a verb card. You must make a correct sentence with that verb, beginning with 'The first time I...' or 'The last time I...'.

4. If your sentence is grammatically correct, your team keeps the card and gets a point.

5. If the other team finds a mistake in your sentence, they can challenge you. If they are right, they steal your card and get the point!

6. The team with the most verbs at the end is the winner.

tags.teacher_instruction: Before the game, have students help you brainstorm 20-30 common regular and irregular verbs to write on the slips of paper. This makes the game more student-centered.

title: A Day in the Life: Sequencing a Story
full_description:
Let's work together to create a story about a person's typical day.

**Part 1: Order the Actions**
• In pairs, look at the list of phrases below. First, change the verbs to the past simple. Then, arrange the phrases in a logical order to describe someone's morning.
• Use words like 'and', 'then', and 'after that' to connect the sentences.

   (Actions: wake up, get up, make coffee, have a shower, check phone, get dressed, leave the house, drive to work/school)

**Part 2: Ask and Answer**
• Write one question about each sentence in your story (e.g., 'What time did he wake up?').
• Join with another pair. Ask and answer your questions.

**Part 3: Continue the Story**
• As a group of four, continue the story of the person's day. What happened at work or school? What did they do in the evening? Choose one person to read your finished story to the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original list of actions has been modernized and simplified for clarity. This activity combines sequencing, question formation, and narrative development.

title: Audio Postcard: Describing a Scene
full_description:
Let's use our listening skills to practice the present continuous.

1. Your teacher will play an audio clip of a busy place (e.g., a city street, a market, an airport).

2. Close your eyes and listen carefully for one to two minutes. Make notes on all the different sounds you can hear. What is happening?

3. In pairs, compare your notes and write a short paragraph describing the scene as if you are there. For example: 'A train is arriving at the station. Many people are talking loudly. A baby is crying.'

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a great listening and writing activity. Instead of relying on the sounds outside the classroom (which may be quiet), find an ambient soundscape video on YouTube (search for 'city ambience', 'restaurant sounds', etc.). This gives you control over the audio input and can be adapted to any theme.

title: Writing a Holiday Update
full_description:
1. In pairs, imagine you are on holiday in your dream location. You are sitting in a café, and it's a busy, interesting place.

2. Write a short social media post or an email to a friend back home.

3. In your message, describe what is happening right now using the present continuous.

4. You should also include:
   • A description of the weather.
   • What people are doing around you.
   • What you are eating and drinking.
   • What you are planning to do tomorrow (use present continuous for future arrangements, e.g., 'Tomorrow we are visiting the museum.').

title: Trends and Changes: Your Life and the World
full_description:
**Part 1: Your Life These Days**
• In pairs, talk about what is happening in your life at the moment. What are you focusing on? What is changing?
• You can discuss topics like:
  • Your studies or apprenticeship
  • Hobbies and interests
  • Your daily routines

**Part 2: The World These Days**
• In small groups, discuss some of the big trends happening in the world right now.
• Consider topics like:
  • Technology (e.g., AI, social media)
  • The environment
  • Culture (e.g., music, fashion, movies)
• Agree on the three most important trends and prepare to share your ideas with the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity helps students practice using the present continuous for longer, ongoing situations, not just actions happening at this exact moment. The original included a diary prompt which has been removed to focus on speaking. Ensure the discussion in Part 2 remains respectful.

title: The Weekend Planner: Making Future Plans
full_description:
Let's practice using the present continuous to talk about future plans.

1. Draw a simple weekend planner with slots for Saturday morning, afternoon, evening, and Sunday morning, afternoon, evening.

2. Fill in any THREE of the six slots with plans you have. You can be creative! For example: 'testing a new video game' or 'going to a concert'.

3. Now, walk around the room and try to make plans with other students to fill your THREE empty slots.

• **Example Conversation:**
  A: 'What are you doing on Saturday afternoon?'
  B: 'I'm meeting a friend for coffee.'
  A: 'Okay. Are you doing anything on Sunday evening?'
  B: 'No, I'm not doing anything. I'm free!'
  A: 'Would you like to see a movie?'

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a classic communicative activity. The original description used 'dairy' instead of 'diary'. This has been corrected. You can suggest students use their actual phone calendars for a modern twist, which makes the role-play more authentic.

title: Describing Annoying Habits with 'Always'
full_description:
We can use 'always' with the present continuous to complain about repeated, annoying habits.

**Part 1: Sharing & Advice**
• In pairs, think of a person you know (IMPORTANT: not someone in this class!) who has an annoying habit. Tell your partner about them using the 'always + -ing' structure. For example: 'My brother is always leaving his dirty dishes in the sink.'
• Give each other some friendly advice.

**Part 2: Guess the Adjective**
• Your teacher will give your pair an adjective.
• Write one sentence describing a person with this quality, using 'always + -ing'.
• Read your sentence to the class (don't say the adjective!) and see if they can guess the word.

tags.teacher_instruction: It is very important to stress that students must not talk about anyone in the class to avoid hurt feelings. The sensitivity warning is included for this reason. For Part 2, distribute these adjectives among the pairs: argumentative, bossy, careless, forgetful, grumpy, lazy, messy, selfish, unreliable.

title: Present Perfect Game Show
full_description:
Let's test your knowledge of past participles with two fast-paced team games!

**Game 1: Verb Race**
• Work in two teams.
• Your teacher will say a verb in the infinitive (e.g., 'go').
• The first team to shout out the correct past participle ('gone') gets a point. If you're wrong, the other team gets the point.

**Game 2: Noughts and Crosses (Tic-Tac-Toe)**
• The teacher will draw a 3x3 grid on the board with a different verb in each square.
• Take turns choosing a square for your team.
• To win the square, you must say the past participle and use it in a correct present perfect sentence. For example, for 'take': 'Taken. I have taken the bus today.'

tags.teacher_instruction: The original activity contained four different drills. This version combines the two most engaging. For Game 1, have a list of common irregular verbs ready to call out. For Game 2, draw the grid and fill it with verbs your students find difficult, like: see, do, be, eat, write, give, make, go, break.

title: Class Survey: Have You Ever...?
full_description:
Let's find out about your classmates' life experiences!

1. Your task is to walk around the room and find a different person who has done each thing on the list below.

2. Ask questions using the present perfect: 'Have you ever...?'

3. When someone answers 'yes', write their name next to the activity on your paper.

tags.teacher_instruction:
This is a classic 'Find Someone Who...' mingle activity. Provide the students with this updated list of experiences:
• crash a car (as a passenger or driver)
• ride a horse
• work a night shift
• sing karaoke in public
• go diving
• make bread from scratch
• win a prize or competition
• sleep outside in a tent
• break a bone
• eat caviar
• climb a mountain
• build your own PC

title: Present Perfect to Past Simple: The Conversation Flow
full_description:
Let's practice how a natural conversation flows from a general experience to specific details.

**Part 1: Pair Conversation**
• In pairs, ask and answer questions starting with 'Have you ever...?' using the topics below.
• If your partner says 'Yes, I have,' ask follow-up questions using the past simple (What...? When...? Where...? Why...?) to find out more.

• **Example Conversation:**
  A: 'Have you ever broken a bone?'
  B: 'Yes, I have.'
  A: 'Wow! When did you see it?'
  B: 'I broke my arm last year when I was playing football.'

• **Topics to discuss:**
  • cut your finger badly
  • eat Indian food
  • see an eclipse
  • live by the sea
  • go on a demonstration
  • do something brave
  • sleep in a tent
  • drive a tractor or boat

**Part 2: What Do You Think?**
• Tell your partner something you've done that you think is unique in the class. Then, guess something they have never done that you think someone else has.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity is crucial for practicing the natural switch from present perfect (for general life experience) to past simple (for specific details of that single event). Model the example conversation clearly on the board to highlight the tense change.

title: Mystery Scene: What Has Happened Here?
full_description:
Let's be detectives and use the present perfect to figure out what has happened based on clues.

**The Situation:**
• Imagine you walk into a room and it's a mess. You are trying to describe what you think has happened based on what you see.

**The Task:**
1. As a class, let's brainstorm some clues we might see. For example: an open window, an empty coffee cup, a knocked-over chair, chocolates on the table, soft music playing.

2. In pairs, look at the clues and make sentences using the present perfect to say what has happened.
   • For example: 'Someone has opened the window.' or 'Someone has made coffee.'

3. Based on the clues, work together to create a short story about the mystery. Was it a thief? Was someone preparing for a date? Be ready to share your theory with the class!

tags.teacher_instruction: The original 'romantic dinner' scenario is outdated and could be uncomfortable for students. This re-theme to a 'mystery scene' is more engaging, flexible, and inclusive. The core grammatical goal (using present perfect to describe the results of past actions) is preserved. You can draw the scene with clues on the board or just list them.

title: The Ultimate Checklist: Are We Ready?
full_description:
Let's practice using the present perfect to check if we are ready for a big event.

1. In pairs or small groups, choose one of the following scenarios:
   • Preparing for a holiday trip
   • Organizing a class party
   • Getting ready for a job interview
   • Preparing a workshop for a project

2. Make a checklist of ten important things that need to be done beforehand.

3. Now, imagine it's time to leave or start the event. Role-play checking your list with your partner.
   • **Example:**
     A: 'Have you packed the towels?'
     B: 'Yes, I have. Have you brought the passports?'
     A: 'Oh no, I haven't! I've forgotten them.'

tags.teacher_instruction: Encourage students to choose a scenario relevant to their vocational studies (e.g., preparing a worksite, setting up for a client, prepping a kitchen for service) as this will increase engagement and allow for specialized vocabulary practice.

title: Predict the Future: A 'Going To' Mime Game
full_description:
Let's practice using 'going to' to talk about future plans and predictions.

**Part 1: Team Quiz**
1. Your teacher will read a sentence describing a situation.
2. In your teams, be the first to guess what is going to happen next. For example, if you hear 'The phone is ringing,' you should say, 'You're going to answer it!'
3. The first team with the correct answer gets a point.

**Part 2: Group Mime Challenge**
1. In small groups, brainstorm and practice miming three different future actions.
2. Take turns miming your actions for the class. The other groups have to guess what you are 'going to do'.

tags.teacher_instruction:
Divide the class into two teams for the quiz part. Use these modernized sentences as prompts. The expected answer is in parentheses.
• I've put on my coat and hat. (I'm going to go out.)
• The phone is ringing. (I'm going to answer it.)
• I've got all the ingredients. (I'm going to make a cake/dinner.)
• I've bought the tickets. (I'm going to the cinema/a concert.)
• I have a headache. (I'm going to take some paracetamol/lie down.)
• It's late and I'm tired. (I'm going to go to bed.)
• The kitchen is full of dirty dishes. (I'm going to do the washing up.)
• It's raining. (I'm going to take the bus/an umbrella.)
• There's a great series on Netflix tonight. (I'm going to watch it.)
• I'm hungry. (I'm going to make a sandwich.)
For the mime part, encourage students to think of modern or job-related activities (e.g., start a video game, repair an engine, film a TikTok video).

title: Future Policies: What Are You Going to Change?
full_description:
Imagine your group is in charge of making improvements. You could be in charge of your school, your workplace, or your local town.

1. In your group, brainstorm a list of problems or things you want to improve.

2. For each problem, decide on a new policy or action you will take. Use the 'going to' future form. For example: 'The canteen is too expensive. We are going to lower the prices.'

3. Prepare a short presentation to announce your new policies to the class.

4. Present your plans. Be prepared to answer questions from your classmates!

tags.teacher_instruction:
This activity encourages students to think critically and use 'going to' for plans and intentions. Frame the task around contexts relevant to their vocational studies (e.g., improving a workshop, redesigning a salon, planning a new IT system).

For a more advanced challenge or to add energy, you can assign different groups opposing roles (e.g., students vs. school management). Encourage respectful debate. You can also use this to practice the past form 'was/were going to' by having groups challenge each other, e.g., 'But you said you were going to cut taxes!'

title: Find Someone Who... (Using 'Have Got')
full_description:
Let's practice using 'have got' to talk about possessions and characteristics.

**Part 1: Pair Questions**
• In pairs, ask and answer questions using 'have got' and the topics your teacher gives you. For example:
A: 'Have you got any pets?'
B: 'Yes, I have. I've got a dog.' / 'No, I haven't.'

**Part 2: Class Mingle**
1. Your teacher will give you one topic.
2. Walk around the classroom and ask everyone about your topic.
3. Your goal is to find out who in the class has got the most of your item (e.g., who has got the most siblings).

**Part 3: Pair Discussion**
• In pairs, tell each other about your home and your country using 'has got'. For example: 'My apartment has got a small balcony.' or 'Norway has got some beautiful fjords.'

tags.teacher_instruction:
This activity practices 'have got', which is common in British and Norwegian-taught English. You can briefly mention that in American English, 'do you have' is more common.

For Part 1, use this list of modernized topics: 
• professional qualifications • brothers or sisters • pets • books • streaming service subscriptions • friends abroad • a gaming setup • tattoos or piercings

For the mingle in Part 2, allocate one of the topics above to each student or pair.

title: Life Admin: Getting Things Done
full_description:
We often pay other people to do things for us. Let's practice talking about this using 'have/get something done'.

**Part 1: Recent Services**
• In small groups, talk about services you have used recently. For example: 'I went to the phone repair shop to get my screen fixed.' or 'I had my hair cut last week.'
• Use the list of people and places below to give you ideas:
  • car mechanic / workshop
  • phone repair shop
  • hairdresser / barber
  • clothing repair shop
  • vet
  • getting professional photos taken

**Part 2: Renovation Plan**
• Imagine your group moves into an old house that needs a lot of work. The renovation is half-finished.
• Write two lists:
  1. Things you have already had done (e.g., 'We've had the windows replaced.')
  2. Things you are going to get done (e.g., 'We're going to get a new kitchen installed.')
• Share your plan with the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: The causative structure 'have/get something done' can be challenging. Part 1 connects it to students' real-life experiences. Part 2 is especially good for vocational students (construction, design, etc.) as it relates to project planning. Before starting, you might want to pre-teach or review vocabulary related to home renovation and services.

title: Why Did You Go? Explaining Your Purpose
full_description:
Let's practice using the infinitive ('to' + verb) to explain the reason for an action.

**Part 1: Why Did You Go?**
• Your teacher will name a place. In pairs, ask and answer 'Why did you go there?'
• For example:
  Teacher: 'The supermarket.'
  Student A: 'Why did you go to the supermarket?'
  Student B: 'I went there to buy some food.'

**Part 2: Your Turn**
1. Write a list of five places you have been to in the last week.
2. Swap lists with your partner.
3. Ask and answer questions about each other's lists.

**Part 3: Sentence Completion**
1. Your teacher will dictate the beginning of some sentences.
2. Write them down and complete them with your own ideas.
3. Compare your finished sentences with your partner.

tags.teacher_instruction:
For Part 1, use this list of modernized places: 
• cinema • train station • hardware store (e.g., Jula) • café • pharmacy (apotek) • a website for booking travel • post office

For Part 3, dictate these sentence starters:
• I'm going to save up to...
• I came to this school to...
• We stopped at the service station to...
• I bought a new computer to...
• I rang customer service to...
• I'm studying English to...
• I went to Sweden to...
• She called me to...

title: What's the Reason? A Purpose Game
full_description:
Let's practice explaining the purpose of different actions.

**Part 1: Brainstorming Reasons**
• In pairs, think of reasons for doing the following things. Use the infinitive of purpose ('to' + verb).
• For example: 'Why do we write?' -> 'We write to communicate with each other.'
• Discuss these actions:
  • study
  • drink coffee or energy drinks
  • exercise
  • sleep
  • work
  • learn English
  • eat
  • use social media

**Part 2: Guess the Activity**
1. In your pairs, think of three activities you do regularly (e.g., play video games, go fishing, watch Netflix).
2. For each activity, write one sentence explaining *why* you do it. Don't name the activity! For example: 'I do this to relax after a long day at school.'
3. Read your reason to the class. Can they guess the activity?

tags.teacher_instruction: The list of actions in Part 1 has been modernized. The original mentioned 'playing the lottery' and 'sighing', which are less common or useful. This version is more focused on students' daily lives.

title: Requests and Promises Practice
full_description:
Let's practice using verbs followed by an infinitive, like 'want to', 'promise to', and 'decide to'.

**Part 1: Making Requests**
1. Work in pairs. Use the pattern 'I want you to...' to give each other instructions or make requests.
2. For example: 'I want you to speak more quietly.' or 'I need you to help me with this.'
3. Try to use different verbs like `want`, `would like`, and `need`.

**Part 2: Sharing Experiences**
1. In pairs, ask and answer questions about the last time you did something from the list below.
2. Use the pattern 'verb + to + verb'. For example: 'I promised to call my friend more often.'
3. Discuss when you last...
  • agreed to do something
  • offered to help someone
  • decided to make a change
  • refused to do something
  • learned to do something new
  • promised to do something
  • hoped to achieve something

tags.teacher_instruction: The original activity used a confusing table. This version simplifies the instructions. For Part 1, you can model the target structure and then have students report back what they asked their partner to do, which practices reported speech (e.g., 'I asked Maria to speak more quietly.').

title: Do You Like vs. Would You Like
full_description:
Let's practice the difference between 'like' (for general preferences) and 'would like' (for specific offers and requests).

**Part 1: Offering Help**
• In pairs, one person states a problem from the list below. The other person offers help using 'Would you like...?'
• For example:
  Student A: 'I'm thirsty.'
  Student B: 'Would you like a drink?'

• Problems:
  • It's cold in here. • I'm hungry. • My phone battery is dead. • I don't understand this exercise. • My bags are heavy.

**Part 2: Sorting and Asking**
1. Your teacher will read out a list of phrases. Listen and write each one under the correct heading: 'Do you like...?' (general) or 'Would you like...?' (specific offer).
2. In pairs, ask and answer questions using both forms. For example:
  A: 'Do you like dogs?' (general)
  B: 'Yes, I do.'
  A: 'Would you like to pet my dog?' (specific offer)
  B: 'Yes, please!'

tags.teacher_instruction:
This is a key distinction for learners. For Part 2, read out these expressions and have students categorise them. You can write the two headings on the board.

• a cup of tea ('Would you like...?')
• tea ('Do you like...?')
• speaking English ('Do you like...?')
• to speak English now ('Would you like...?')
• cats ('Do you like...?')
• meeting celebrities ('Do you like...?')
• to meet Erling Haaland ('Would you like...?')
• going to the cinema ('Do you like...?')
• to go to the cinema tonight ('Would you like...?')

title: Describing People, Places, and Things
full_description:
**Part 1: What's it like?**
• In pairs, ask and answer questions about a city you know well using 'What is/are... like?'
• For example:
  A: 'What's the public transport like?'
  B: 'It's fast and efficient.'
• Use these topics: food, music, shops, people, weather.

**Part 2: People and Preferences**
• In small groups, practice the difference between 'What is... like?' (describing personality) and 'What does... like?' (describing preferences).
• For example:
  A: 'What's your best friend like?'
  B: 'He's very funny and kind.'
  A: 'What does your best friend like?'
  B: 'He likes gaming and football.'

**Part 3: Question Challenge**
• Listen to your teacher's answers and shout out the correct question: 'What's ... like?', 'What does ... look like?', 'What does ... like?', or 'How is ...?'
• For example:
  Teacher: 'He's very tall.'
  Class: 'What does he look like?'

tags.teacher_instruction:
This activity clarifies several confusing question forms. The original included four separate activities which have been combined and streamlined here. For Part 3, use these answers to elicit the questions:
1. What's ... like? (description/character)
2. What does ... look like? (physical appearance)
3. What does ... like? (preferences)
4. How is ...? (current state/feeling)

• He's happy. (How is he?)
• The dog is black. (What does it look like?)
• Maria likes music. (What does she like?)
• Oslo is cold in winter. (What's it like?)
• It is very beautiful. (What's it like?)
• I'm exhausted. (How are you?)
• He has got grey hair. (What does he look like?)

title: Guess the Simile
full_description:
A simile is a phrase that compares one thing to another using 'like' or 'as'. Let's practice with some common ones.

1. Your teacher will give your group a simile.

2. In your group, write a short story or situation that ends with your simile. For example, for the simile 'as white as a ghost', your story could be: 'I walked into the dark room and suddenly a hand grabbed my shoulder. I turned around and saw my friend's face. He looked as white as a ghost.'

3. Read your story to the class, but don't say the final simile. See if the other groups can guess which simile completes your story!

tags.teacher_instruction:
The original similes were very idiomatic and culturally specific. This version uses more transparent and common similes suitable for B2 learners. Write these on the board and allocate one to each group:
• He runs as fast as the wind.
• She slept like a log.
• He is as strong as an ox.
• Her smile was as bright as the sun.
• He was as busy as a bee.
• It was as cold as ice.

title: Describing Impressions with 'Like' and 'As If'
full_description:
We can use 'like' and 'as if' to describe our impressions of things, especially with verbs of perception (look, sound, feel, taste).

• **'like' + noun:** 'You look like your brother.'
• **'as if' + clause (subject + verb):** 'You look as if you have seen a ghost.'

1. In small groups, use the prompts below to write two sentences for each: one with 'like' and one with 'as if'.
2. For example, for 'He looks...':
   • Sentence 1 (like): 'He looks like a famous actor.'
   • Sentence 2 (as if): 'He looks as if he hasn't slept for a week.'

**Prompts:**
• You look ...
• This coffee tastes ...
• The film sounds ...
• It feels ...
• Your job sounds ...

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a focused grammar writing task. The original list of prompts was very long; this version is shortened to the most useful ones for students.

title: How It's Made: Describing Processes
full_description:
Let's use the passive voice to describe processes.

**Part 1: Products and Materials**
• In pairs, discuss the relationship between these pairs of words. How does one become the other?
  • Grapes / Wine
  • Wheat / Bread
  • Trees / Paper
  • Sheep's wool / A sweater
  • Crude oil / Plastic

**Part 2: Explaining a Process**
1. In your group, choose one of the pairs from Part 1 or another process you know (e.g., from your vocational field).
2. List the stages of the process using the passive voice. For example, for 'cacao / chocolate':
  'First, the cacao seeds are picked and dried. Then, they are shipped to the factory. At the factory, they are roasted...'
3. Prepare to present your process to the class.

**Part 3: A Personal Process**
• Think about the process you followed when you first enrolled at this school. Describe the steps to a partner. For example: 'First, I was sent an information packet. Then, I was asked to fill in a form...'

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity is excellent for vocational students as describing processes is a key skill in many fields. Encourage them to choose a process from their studies (e.g., how a car engine is repaired, how a website is built, how a hairstyle is created). The original included a listening component which has been removed to streamline the activity.

title: Who Made It? A Passive Voice Quiz
full_description:
Let's play a quiz game using the passive voice to talk about famous inventions, discoveries, and creations.

1. Your class will be split into two groups.

2. In your group, write five quiz clues using the passive voice. Three clues must be about items from the list below. Two clues can be about any other famous thing you choose.
   • Example: 'It was invented by Tim Berners-Lee.' (Answer: The World Wide Web)

3. When you are ready, take turns testing the other group with your clues.

**List of Items:**
• The Theory of Relativity • The iPhone • Penicillin • The telephone • The Star Wars films • The game 'Minecraft' • The social media app 'TikTok'

tags.teacher_instruction: The list of items has been modernized to be more relevant and recognizable to students in 2025. This makes the quiz more engaging. The original list included items like 'Das Kapital' and 'psychoanalysis', which are less suitable for a general B1/B2 audience.

title: What Happened? Spontaneous Passive Practice
full_description:
Let's practice reacting to situations quickly using the passive voice.

Your teacher will ask you a question about a situation. You need to answer spontaneously with a creative explanation using the passive voice.

For example:
• Teacher: 'What happened to your hand?'
• Student: 'Oh, it was bitten by a dog!'

Don't worry about being realistic – you can be funny or creative! If one student is thinking, another student can jump in with an answer.

tags.teacher_instruction:
This is a fast-paced oral drill. Ask the questions to individual students at random to keep everyone engaged. Use these or similar questions:
• What happened to your arm?
• Why is your bike broken?
• Why are you looking so disappointed?
• Where is your bag?
• Why are you so late?
• What's wrong with your phone?

title: From Headline to News Story
full_description:
Newspaper headlines often use a form of the passive voice. Let's turn these headlines into full news stories.

1. In small groups, your teacher will give you a few headlines.

2. Rewrite each headline as a full sentence using the passive voice. For example, for the headline 'RARE PAINTING STOLEN', you could write: 'A rare painting was stolen from the local museum last night.'

3. Continue the story with one or two more sentences to create a short news report.

4. Share your news reports with the class.

**Headlines:**
• NEW BRIDGE OPENED IN OSLO
• STOLEN ART RECOVERED BY POLICE
• LOCAL SCHOOLS CLOSED DUE TO STORM
• TESLA FACTORY TO BE BUILT IN NORWAY
• NEW RECORD SET AT BISLETT GAMES
• CURE FOR CANCER DISCOVERED (This one is fictional!)

tags.teacher_instruction: The headlines have been updated to be more realistic, modern, and locally relevant for Norwegian students. The original list contained silly headlines like 'Man abducted by aliens' and 'Aussies beaten - at last'. Allocate a few headlines to each group to work on.

title: Modernizing Your Town and School
full_description:
Let's use the passive voice to talk about changes.

**Part 1: Changes in Your Town**
• Imagine you return to your home town after being away for ten years. Many things have changed.
• In small groups, write sentences describing these changes using the present perfect passive ('has/have been...') or past perfect passive ('had been...').
• For example: 'A brand new shopping centre has been built.' or 'The old factory had been demolished.'

**Part 2: What Should Be Changed?**
1. In your groups, discuss some changes that you think should be made to the area where you live now. Use the passive with modal verbs ('should be...').
   • Example: 'The main road should be made into a pedestrian zone.'
2. Now, discuss changes you think should be made to this school or classroom.
3. Be ready to share your best ideas with the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity connects complex grammar (passive with perfect and modal forms) to students' own environment, making it more meaningful. Part 2 is a great opportunity for students to voice their opinions about their school and community in a structured way.

title: Two Truths and a Lie: What Were You Doing?
full_description:
Let's play a game to practice the past continuous.

**Part 1: The Alibi Game**
1. In small groups, your teacher will give you some times from yesterday (e.g., 10:00, 15:30, 20:00).
2. For each time, you must say what you were doing.
3. Here's the challenge: Two of your answers must be true, but one must be a lie.
4. After you share your three 'alibis', your group members will ask you questions and try to guess which one is the lie.

**Part 2: Unlikely Stories**
1. In your group, take turns picking a card with an unlikely activity on it.
2. You must create a short story explaining that you were doing this activity at 7 a.m. yesterday. For example: 'At 7 a.m. yesterday morning, I was flying in a hot air balloon.'
3. The other students will ask you questions to test your story. Try to be convincing!

tags.teacher_instruction:
For Part 2, write some of these modern and unlikely activities on small pieces of paper for students to draw from:
• winning an e-sports tournament
• saving someone's life
• bungee jumping
• hitch-hiking to another country
• sailing across the ocean
• riding a reindeer
• having an operation
• swimming with sharks
• having lunch with a celebrity

title: Setting the Scene: A Creative Writing Task
full_description:
**Part 1: Story Starters**
1. Read the first lines of the stories below.
2. On your own, write a few more sentences for each one to 'set the scene'. Use the past continuous to describe what was happening. For example: 'When we left the hotel it was a fine evening... The sun was setting and a gentle breeze was blowing from the sea.'
   • The office was in a terrible state this morning...
   • When I arrived, the party was in full swing...
   • It was a beautiful spring morning...
   • I only left the children for a minute and when I got back...
3. In a small group, share your ideas. Choose the best one and continue the story together.

**Part 2: What Was Happening When...?**
• In pairs, discuss what was happening at these moments:
  • ...you came into class today.
  • ...you last switched on the TV or opened YouTube.
  • ...you got home yesterday.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity combines creative writing with personal discussion, providing varied practice. The story starters are generic enough to be timeless.

title: The Alibi: A Detective Role-Play
full_description:
There was a crime last night, and we have two suspects!

**The Roles:**
• **Suspects (2 students):** Your job is to create a story together. You must agree on every detail of what you were doing between 7:15 p.m. and 8:15 p.m. last night. You will be questioned separately.
• **Investigators (the rest of the class):** Your job is to find holes in the suspects' story. Work in two groups to prepare a list of detailed questions.

**The Process:**
1. The two suspects go outside the classroom to create their alibi.
2. The investigators work in two groups to write their questions. Think of details: What were you wearing? What were you eating? What music was playing?
3. Each investigator group will question one suspect.
4. After the first round, the groups swap suspects and ask the same questions again.
5. As a class, compare the answers. Did the stories match? Are the suspects guilty or not guilty?

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a highly engaging activity for practicing past tenses, especially the past continuous for setting a scene ('We were watching a movie...') and past simple for key events ('...when the phone rang.'). Choose two willing students to be the suspects. The 'crime' can be something simple and fun, like 'stealing the teacher's coffee mug'.

title: A Day in the Life: Sequencing a Story
full_description:
**Part 1: Order the Actions**
1. In pairs, look at the list of phrases your teacher provides.
2. First, change the verbs to the past simple. Then, arrange the phrases in a logical order to describe someone's morning routine.
3. Connect your sentences using words like 'and', 'then', and 'after that'.

**Part 2: Ask and Answer**
1. For each sentence in your story, write one question (e.g., 'What time did he wake up?').
2. Join with another pair to make a group of four. Ask and answer your questions.

**Part 3: Continue the Story**
1. As a group, continue the story of the person's day. What happened at work or school?
2. Choose one person to read your finished story to the class.

tags.teacher_instruction:
Provide students with this modernized list of actions to put in order:
• wake up
• get up
• make coffee
• have a shower
• check phone
• get dressed
• leave the house
• drive to work/school

title: Cause and Effect: Connecting Past Actions
full_description:
**Part 1: Sentence Building**
1. Your teacher will dictate pairs of short sentences. For example: 'The movie ended. Everyone clapped.'
2. Your task is to join each pair into a single sentence using the past simple and starting with 'when'. For example: 'When the movie ended, everyone clapped.'

**Part 2: Create Your Own**
1. On your own, write two or three pairs of simple cause-and-effect sentences about your own life.
2. Swap your sentences with a partner. Join the sentences you receive using 'when' and then pass them back.

tags.teacher_instruction:
For Part 1, dictate these modernized sentence pairs for students to join:
1. She read the letter. She threw it in the bin.
2. The bell rang. They ran out of the classroom.
3. The rain stopped. We went outside.
4. I got home. I switched on the TV.

title: Pronoun Drill: Mine vs. My
full_description:
**Part 1: Class Drill**
• Listen to the sentence your teacher says. Your job is to shout out the same sentence, but using a possessive pronoun.
• For example:
  Teacher: 'It's my book.'
  Class: 'The book is mine!'

**Part 2: Memory Challenge**
• In pairs, try to write down all the sentence pairs from the drill from memory.

tags.teacher_instruction:
This is a quick oral drill. Use these modernized prompts for Part 1. The original 'That is my man' has been removed.
• It's my pen.
• It's her phone.
• That's my bag.
• It's your car.
• This is our project.
• It's their table.
• This is his laptop.
• That's their dog.

title: Whose Is It Anyway? A Possession Game
full_description:
Let's play a game to practice asking about who owns what.

1. Your teacher will borrow some small objects from the class.

2. In pairs, one person will pick an object and ask their partner about it.

3. Use this conversation as a model:
   • Student A: (holding a pen) 'Is this yours?'
   • Student B: 'No, it's not mine.'
   • Student A: 'Whose is it then?'
   • Student B: 'I think it's his/hers/Maria's.'

4. Take turns practicing the conversation with different objects.

tags.teacher_instruction: Before the activity, collect some small, common objects from the students (e.g., a pen, a phone, an eraser, a notebook) and put them in a bag or box. Model the target conversation on the board. As students get more confident, you can gradually erase the model to challenge their memory.

title: Comparing Possessions: 'What About Yours?'
full_description:
1. Look at the example question: 'My phone is new; what about yours?'

2. In pairs, change the noun ('phone') and the adjective ('new') to create five new questions of your own. Use items you can see in the classroom.
   • For example: 'My jacket is black; what about yours?' or 'My laptop is old; what about yours?'

3. Find a new partner.

4. Take turns asking and answering your five questions.

title: Present Continuous Sentence Completion
full_description:
1. Your teacher will dictate the beginning of several sentences. Write them down.

2. In pairs, think of a logical ending for each sentence using the present continuous (-ing form). For example, if the teacher says 'Don't disturb me...', you could finish with '...I'm working on something important.'

3. After completing the list, create two more of your own sentences that you might use in daily life or at work.

tags.teacher_instruction:
Dictate these modernized sentence starters:
• Don't disturb me; I'm...
• Don't listen to him; he's...
• Quick! Pass the tool; I'm...
• I can't talk right now; I'm...
• Drink your coffee; it's...
• Leave the video on; I'm...
• Look at that car; it's...
• Shhh! Listen. The baby is...

title: What's Everyone Doing? Describing a Scene
full_description:
1. Look at the scene your teacher is drawing on the board (e.g., a school, a workshop, an office building).

2. As a class, let's identify the different rooms or areas and decide who might be there.

3. In small groups, imagine it's a busy time of day. Discuss and agree on what each person is doing right now. Use the present continuous.
   • For example: 'In the workshop, Karim is fixing an engine.' or 'In the canteen, Lise is listening to a podcast.'

4. Now, think about your own family and friends. In your groups, discuss what you think they are doing right now.

tags.teacher_instruction: To make it more relevant for vocational students, you could draw their school, a workshop, a salon, or an office building instead of a generic house. This makes the context more meaningful. Elicit vocabulary for the different areas before starting the group task.

title: Habits vs. Now: A Clothing Conversation
full_description:
Let's practice the difference between the present simple (for habits) and the present continuous (for actions happening now).

Your teacher will start a chain of questions. Listen carefully to decide if the question is about habits ('Do you wear...') or what is happening now ('Are you wearing...?').

• **Example 1 (happening now):**
  Teacher: 'Manuel, are you wearing jeans?'
  Manuel: 'No, I'm not. Ilona, are you wearing jeans?'

• **Example 2 (general habit):**
  Teacher: 'Brigit, do you wear a scarf in winter?'
  Brigit: 'Yes, I do. Peter, do you wear a scarf in winter?'

title: Action Mime Challenge
full_description:
Let's play a game of mime to practice the present continuous.

**Part 1: Teacher's Turn**
• Watch your teacher mime an action. Guess what they are doing by saying, 'You are [verb]-ing.' For example: 'You are driving a car.'

**Part 2: Team Challenge**
• Work in two teams.
• One person from your team will come to the front and mime an action.
• Your team has 30 seconds to guess the action correctly to score a point.

tags.teacher_instruction:
Miming can make some students feel self-conscious, so maintain a fun and supportive atmosphere. The sensitivity warning is included as some students may feel uncomfortable performing in front of the class. For your mime in Part 1, and as suggestions for students, use this updated list of actions:
• flying a drone
• watching a tennis match
• scrolling on TikTok
• listening to a podcast
• taking a selfie
• playing a video game

title: Listening to the World: A Soundscape Activity
full_description:
**Part 1: What's Happening Outside?**
1. We will all be quiet for two minutes.
2. Listen carefully. Make a note of anything you can hear happening outside the classroom.
3. Use the present continuous to describe the sounds. For example: 'A car is driving by.' or 'Someone is talking loudly on their phone.'

**Part 2: Imagined Location**
• Now, imagine you are in a different, busy location (e.g., at a music festival, in a busy restaurant, at an airport).
• Write a short description of all the things that are happening around you.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a great mindfulness and observation activity. If the area outside your classroom is very quiet, you can play an ambient soundscape video from a resource like YouTube (e.g., 'city sounds', 'restaurant ambience') for Part 1.

title: Digital Postcard: A Holiday Update
full_description:
1. In pairs, imagine you are on holiday in your dream location. You are sitting in a café, and there's a lot going on around you.

2. Write a short social media post or an email to a friend back home.

3. In your message, describe what is happening right now using the present continuous. Include descriptions of:
   • the weather
   • the people you can see
   • what you are eating and drinking
   • your plans for the next day (e.g., 'Tomorrow we are visiting the museum.')

title: Trends and Changes: Your Life and the World
full_description:
**Part 1: Your Life These Days**
• In pairs, tell each other what is happening in your life at the moment. What are you studying? What are you working on? What hobbies are you pursuing?

**Part 2: The World These Days**
• In small groups, discuss what is happening in the wider world. What are some of the big changes or trends you are seeing?
• Talk about some of the following topics:
  • Technology and AI
  • The environment
  • The global economy
  • Culture, fashion, or music
• Agree on a list of the three most important trends and share them with the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original activity included a diary-writing prompt which has been removed to focus on speaking. This activity helps students use the present continuous for ongoing trends, not just actions happening 'right now'. Ensure discussions in Part 2 remain respectful.

title: The Weekend Planner: Making Future Plans
full_description:
Let's practice using the present continuous to talk about future plans.

1. Draw a simple weekend planner with slots for Saturday morning, afternoon, evening, and Sunday morning, afternoon, evening.

2. Fill in any THREE of the six slots with plans you have. You can be creative! For example: 'testing a new video game' or 'going to a concert'.

3. Now, walk around the room and try to make plans with other students to fill your THREE empty slots.

• **Example Conversation:**
  A: 'What are you doing on Saturday afternoon?'
  B: 'I'm meeting a friend for coffee.'
  A: 'Okay. Are you doing anything on Sunday evening?'
  B: 'No, I'm not doing anything. I'm free!'
  A: 'Would you like to see a movie?'

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a classic communicative activity. The original description used 'dairy' instead of 'diary'. This has been corrected. You can suggest students use their actual phone calendars for a modern twist, which makes the role-play more authentic.

title: Always Complaining: Describing Annoying Habits
full_description:
We can use 'always' with the present continuous to complain about repeated, annoying habits.

**Part 1: Sharing & Advice**
• In pairs, think of a person you know (IMPORTANT: not someone in this class!) who has an annoying habit. Tell your partner about them using the 'always + -ing' structure. For example: 'My brother is always leaving his dirty dishes in the sink.'
• Give each other some friendly advice.

**Part 2: Guess the Adjective**
• Your teacher will give your pair an adjective.
• Write one sentence describing a person with this quality, using 'always + -ing'.
• Read your sentence to the class (don't say the adjective!) and see if they can guess the word.

tags.teacher_instruction: It is very important to stress that students must not talk about anyone in the class to avoid hurt feelings. The sensitivity warning is included for this reason. For Part 2, distribute these adjectives among the pairs: argumentative, bossy, careless, forgetful, greedy, grumpy, lazy, mean, moody, selfish, unreliable, untidy.

title: Present Perfect Game Show
full_description:
Let's test your knowledge of past participles with two fast-paced team games!

**Game 1: Verb Race**
• Work in two teams.
• Your teacher will say a verb in the infinitive (e.g., 'go').
• The first team to shout out the correct past participle ('gone') gets a point. If you're wrong, the other team gets the point.

**Game 2: Noughts and Crosses (Tic-Tac-Toe)**
• The teacher will draw a 3x3 grid on the board with a different verb in each square.
• Take turns choosing a square for your team.
• To win the square, you must say the past participle and use it in a correct present perfect sentence. For example, for 'take': 'Taken. I have taken the bus today.'

tags.teacher_instruction: The original activity contained four different drills. This version combines the two most engaging. For Game 1, have a list of common irregular verbs ready to call out. For Game 2, draw the grid and fill it with verbs your students find difficult, like: see, do, be, eat, write, give, make, go, break.

title: Class Survey: Have You Ever...?
full_description:
Let's find out about your classmates' life experiences!

1. Your task is to walk around the room and find a different person who has done each thing on the list below.

2. Ask questions using the present perfect: 'Have you ever...?'

3. When someone answers 'yes', write their name next to the activity on your paper.

tags.teacher_instruction:
This is a classic 'Find Someone Who...' mingle activity. Provide the students with this updated list of experiences:
• crash a car (as a passenger or driver)
• ride a horse
• work a night shift
• sing karaoke in public
• go diving
• make bread from scratch
• win a prize or competition
• sleep outside in a tent
• break a bone
• eat caviar
• climb a mountain
• build your own PC

title: From Experience to Detail: A Conversation Guide
full_description:
**Part 1: Pair Conversation**
• In pairs, ask and answer questions starting with 'Have you ever...?' using the topics below.
• If your partner says 'Yes, I have,' ask follow-up questions using the past simple (What...? When...? Where...? Why...?) to find out more.

• **Example:**
  A: 'Have you ever broken a bone?'
  B: 'Yes, I have.'
  A: 'Oh really? What happened?'
  B: 'I broke my arm when I was playing football at school.'
